<h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" lang="en">George W. Bush</h1>
<div class="mw-body-content" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div class="mw-jump" id="jump-to-nav">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-head">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
</div>
<div class="mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">This article is about the 43rd President of the United States. For his father, the 41st President, see <a href="/wiki/George_H._W._Bush" title="George H. W. Bush">George H. W. Bush</a>. For the American settler, see <a href="/wiki/George_Washington_Bush" title="George Washington Bush">George Washington Bush</a>.</div>

<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/United_States_Aviator_Badge#United_States_Air_Force" title="United States Aviator Badge">Air Force Pilot's Badge</a></li>
<li><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Outstanding_Unit_ribbon.svg"><img alt="Outstanding Unit ribbon.svg" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="30" data-file-width="106" height="7" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Outstanding_Unit_ribbon.svg/23px-Outstanding_Unit_ribbon.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Outstanding_Unit_ribbon.svg/35px-Outstanding_Unit_ribbon.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Outstanding_Unit_ribbon.svg/46px-Outstanding_Unit_ribbon.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a> <a href="/wiki/Air_Force_Outstanding_Unit_Award" title="Air Force Outstanding Unit Award">Outstanding Unit Award</a></li>
<li><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:National_Defense_Service_Medal_ribbon.svg"><img alt="National Defense Service Medal ribbon.svg" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="279" data-file-width="1024" height="6" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/National_Defense_Service_Medal_ribbon.svg/23px-National_Defense_Service_Medal_ribbon.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/National_Defense_Service_Medal_ribbon.svg/35px-National_Defense_Service_Medal_ribbon.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/National_Defense_Service_Medal_ribbon.svg/46px-National_Defense_Service_Medal_ribbon.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a> <a href="/wiki/National_Defense_Service_Medal" title="National Defense Service Medal">National Defense Service Medal</a></li>
<li><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:USAF_Marksmanship_ribbon.svg"><img alt="USAF Marksmanship ribbon.svg" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="30" data-file-width="106" height="7" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/USAF_Marksmanship_ribbon.svg/23px-USAF_Marksmanship_ribbon.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/USAF_Marksmanship_ribbon.svg/35px-USAF_Marksmanship_ribbon.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/USAF_Marksmanship_ribbon.svg/46px-USAF_Marksmanship_ribbon.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a> <a href="/wiki/Marksmanship_Ribbon#Air_Force" title="Marksmanship Ribbon">Small Arms Expert Marksmanship Ribbon</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup></li>
</ul>
</div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>

<a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Seal_of_the_President_of_the_United_States.svg"><img alt="Seal of the President of the United States.svg" data-file-height="2425" data-file-width="2424" height="60" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Seal_of_the_President_of_the_United_States.svg/60px-Seal_of_the_President_of_the_United_States.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Seal_of_the_President_of_the_United_States.svg/90px-Seal_of_the_President_of_the_United_States.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Seal_of_the_President_of_the_United_States.svg/120px-Seal_of_the_President_of_the_United_States.svg.png 2x" width="60"/></a></td>

<tr>
<td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%;text-align:center;">
<div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini">
<ul>
<li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:George_W._Bush_series" title="Template:George W. Bush series"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li>
<li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:George_W._Bush_series" title="Template talk:George W. Bush series"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li>
<li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:George_W._Bush_series&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p><b>George Walker Bush</b> (born July 6, 1946) is an American politician who served as the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_the_United_States" title="List of Presidents of the United States">43rd President of the United States</a> from 2001 to 2009. He was also the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Governors_of_Texas" title="List of Governors of Texas">46th Governor of Texas</a> from 1995 to 2000. After graduating from <a href="/wiki/Yale_University" title="Yale University">Yale University</a> in 1968 and <a href="/wiki/Harvard_Business_School" title="Harvard Business School">Harvard Business School</a> in 1975, he worked in the oil industry. Bush married <a href="/wiki/Laura_Bush" title="Laura Bush">Laura Welch</a> in 1977 and ran unsuccessfully for the <a href="/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives" title="United States House of Representatives">House of Representatives</a> shortly thereafter. He later co-owned the <a href="/wiki/Texas_Rangers_(baseball)" title="Texas Rangers (baseball)">Texas Rangers</a> baseball team before defeating <a href="/wiki/Ann_Richards" title="Ann Richards">Ann Richards</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Texas_gubernatorial_election,_1994" title="Texas gubernatorial election, 1994">1994 Texas gubernatorial election</a>. Bush was elected president in 2000 after a <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2000" title="United States presidential election, 2000">close and controversial win</a> over Democratic rival <a href="/wiki/Al_Gore" title="Al Gore">Al Gore</a>, becoming the fourth president to be elected while receiving fewer popular votes than his opponent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-3"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup></p>
<p>From a prominent political <a href="/wiki/Bush_family" title="Bush family">family</a>, he is the eldest son of <a href="/wiki/Barbara_Bush" title="Barbara Bush">Barbara</a> and <a href="/wiki/George_H._W._Bush" title="George H. W. Bush">George H. W. Bush</a>, the 41st President of the United States, making him only the second president to assume the nation's highest office after his father, following the lead of <a href="/wiki/John_Quincy_Adams" title="John Quincy Adams">John Quincy Adams</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-4"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup> His brother, <a href="/wiki/Jeb_Bush" title="Jeb Bush">Jeb Bush</a>, a former <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Governor_of_Florida" title="Governor of Florida">Governor of Florida</a>, was a candidate for the <a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" title="Republican Party (United States)">Republican</a> presidential nomination in the <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2016" title="United States presidential election, 2016">2016 presidential election</a>. His paternal grandfather, <a href="/wiki/Prescott_Bush" title="Prescott Bush">Prescott Bush</a>, was a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_Senator" title="United States Senator">United States Senator</a> from <a href="/wiki/Connecticut" title="Connecticut">Connecticut</a>.</p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">September 11 terrorist attacks</a> occurred eight months into Bush's first term as president. Bush responded with what became known as the <a href="/wiki/Bush_Doctrine" title="Bush Doctrine">Bush Doctrine</a>: launching a "<a href="/wiki/War_on_Terror" title="War on Terror">War on Terror</a>", an international military campaign that included the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%9314)" title="War in Afghanistan (2001–14)">war in Afghanistan</a> in 2001 and the <a href="/wiki/Iraq_War" title="Iraq War">Iraq War</a> in 2003. He also promoted policies on the economy, health care, education, Social Security reform, and <a href="/wiki/Federal_Marriage_Amendment" title="Federal Marriage Amendment">amending</a> the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Constitution" title="United States Constitution">Constitution</a> to prohibit <a href="/wiki/Same-sex_marriage" title="Same-sex marriage">same-sex marriage</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-5"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup> He signed into law <a href="/wiki/Bush_tax_cuts" title="Bush tax cuts">broad tax cuts</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Patriot_Act" title="Patriot Act">Patriot Act</a>, the <a href="/wiki/No_Child_Left_Behind_Act" title="No Child Left Behind Act">No Child Left Behind Act</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Partial-Birth_Abortion_Ban_Act" title="Partial-Birth Abortion Ban Act">Partial-Birth Abortion Ban Act</a>, <a href="/wiki/Medicare_(United_States)" title="Medicare (United States)">Medicare</a> prescription drug benefits for seniors, and funding for the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/AIDS" title="AIDS">AIDS</a> relief program known as <a href="/wiki/President%27s_Emergency_Plan_for_AIDS_Relief" title="President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief">PEPFAR</a>. His tenure included national debates on <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_the_United_States" title="Immigration to the United States">immigration</a>, <a href="/wiki/Social_Security_(United_States)" title="Social Security (United States)">Social Security</a>, <a href="/wiki/Terrorist_Surveillance_Program" title="Terrorist Surveillance Program">electronic surveillance</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Enhanced_interrogation_techniques" title="Enhanced interrogation techniques">torture</a>.</p>
<p>In the <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2004" title="United States presidential election, 2004">2004</a> Presidential race, Bush defeated Democratic Senator <a href="/wiki/John_Kerry" title="John Kerry">John Kerry</a> in another relatively close election. After his re-election, Bush received increasingly heated <a href="/wiki/Public_image_of_George_W._Bush" title="Public image of George W. Bush">criticism</a> from across the <a href="/wiki/Political_spectrum" title="Political spectrum">political spectrum</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Republican_right_abandoning_Bush_6-0"><a href="#cite_note-Republican_right_abandoning_Bush-6">[6]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kelley_Beaucar_Vlahos_7-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kelley_Beaucar_Vlahos-7">[7]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Baker_8-0"><a href="#cite_note-Baker-8">[8]</a></sup> for his handling of the Iraq War, <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Katrina" title="Hurricane Katrina">Hurricane Katrina</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TVNZ_9-0"><a href="#cite_note-TVNZ-9">[9]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mike_M._Ahlers_10-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mike_M._Ahlers-10">[10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_11-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-11">[11]</a></sup> and other challenges. Amid this criticism, the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)" title="Democratic Party (United States)">Democratic Party</a> regained control of Congress in the <a href="/wiki/United_States_elections,_2006" title="United States elections, 2006">2006 elections</a>. In December 2007, the United States entered its longest post-<a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> recession, often referred to as the "<a href="/wiki/Great_Recession" title="Great Recession">Great Recession</a>", prompting the Bush administration to obtain congressional passage of multiple economic programs intended to preserve the country's financial system. Nationally, Bush was both one of the most popular and unpopular presidents in history, having received the highest recorded presidential approval ratings in the wake of the September 11 attacks, as well as one of the lowest approval ratings during the <a href="/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%932008" title="Financial crisis of 2007–2008">2008 financial crisis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gallup_12-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gallup-12">[12]</a></sup></p>
<p>Bush left office in 2009, returning to Texas where he purchased a home in Dallas. In 2010, he published his memoir, <i><a href="/wiki/Decision_Points" title="Decision Points">Decision Points</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush_Presidential_Center" title="George W. Bush Presidential Center">His presidential library</a> was opened in 2013. His presidency has been ranked among the worst in historians' polls published in the late 2000s and 2010s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-US_News_14-0"><a href="#cite_note-US_News-14">[14]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Austin_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-Austin-15">[15]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mann_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mann-16">[16]</a></sup></p>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-13"><a href="#Presidency_.282001.E2.80.932009.29"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Presidency (2001–2009)</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-14"><a href="#Domestic_policy"><span class="tocnumber">4.1</span> <span class="toctext">Domestic policy</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-15"><a href="#Economic_policy"><span class="tocnumber">4.1.1</span> <span class="toctext">Economic policy</span></a></li>

<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-18"><a href="#Environmental_policies"><span class="tocnumber">4.1.4</span> <span class="toctext">Environmental policies</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-19"><a href="#Energy_policies"><span class="tocnumber">4.1.5</span> <span class="toctext">Energy policies</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-20"><a href="#Stem_cell_research_and_first_veto"><span class="tocnumber">4.1.6</span> <span class="toctext">Stem cell research and first veto</span></a></li>

<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-25"><a href="#Purge_of_the_Central_Intelligence_Agency"><span class="tocnumber">4.1.11</span> <span class="toctext">Purge of the Central Intelligence Agency</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-26"><a href="#Foreign_policy"><span class="tocnumber">4.2</span> <span class="toctext">Foreign policy</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-27"><a href="#September_11_attacks"><span class="tocnumber">4.2.1</span> <span class="toctext">September 11 attacks</span></a></li>

<ul>

</div>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life_and_career">Early life and career</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Early_life_of_George_W._Bush" title="Early life of George W. Bush">Early life of George W. Bush</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GeorgeWBush1947.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1781" data-file-width="1620" height="242" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/GeorgeWBush1947.png/220px-GeorgeWBush1947.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/GeorgeWBush1947.png/330px-GeorgeWBush1947.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/GeorgeWBush1947.png/440px-GeorgeWBush1947.png 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GeorgeWBush1947.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
George W. Bush with his parents, Barbara and George H. W. Bush, <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr> 1947, when <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Harry_Truman" title="Harry Truman">Harry Truman</a> was the president</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>George Walker Bush was born on July 6, 1946, at Grace-New Haven Hospital (now <a href="/wiki/Yale%E2%80%93New_Haven_Hospital" title="Yale–New Haven Hospital">Yale–New Haven Hospital</a>) in <a href="/wiki/New_Haven,_Connecticut" title="New Haven, Connecticut">New Haven, Connecticut</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> as the first child of <a href="/wiki/George_H._W._Bush" title="George H. W. Bush">George Herbert Walker Bush</a> and his wife, the former <a href="/wiki/Barbara_Bush" title="Barbara Bush">Barbara Pierce</a>. He was raised in <a href="/wiki/Midland,_Texas" title="Midland, Texas">Midland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Houston" title="Houston">Houston, Texas</a>, with four siblings, <a href="/wiki/Jeb_Bush" title="Jeb Bush">Jeb</a>, <a href="/wiki/Neil_Bush" title="Neil Bush">Neil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marvin_Bush" title="Marvin Bush">Marvin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dorothy_Bush_Koch" title="Dorothy Bush Koch">Dorothy</a>. Another younger sister, Robin, died from <a href="/wiki/Leukemia" title="Leukemia">leukemia</a> at the age of three in 1953.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup> His grandfather, <a href="/wiki/Prescott_Bush" title="Prescott Bush">Prescott Bush</a>, was a U.S. Senator from <a href="/wiki/Connecticut" title="Connecticut">Connecticut</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> His father, George H.W. Bush, was <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a>'s Vice President from 1981 to 1989 and the 41st U.S. President from 1989 to 1993. Bush has <a href="/wiki/English_Americans" title="English Americans">English</a> and some <a href="/wiki/German_Americans" title="German Americans">German</a> ancestry, along with more distant <a href="/wiki/Dutch_Americans" title="Dutch Americans">Dutch</a>, <a href="/wiki/Welsh_Americans" title="Welsh Americans">Welsh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Irish_Americans" title="Irish Americans">Irish</a>, <a href="/wiki/French_Americans" title="French Americans">French</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Americans" title="Scottish Americans">Scottish</a> roots.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>
<p>Bush attended public schools in <a href="/wiki/Midland,_Texas" title="Midland, Texas">Midland, Texas</a>, until the family moved to Houston after he had completed seventh grade. He then spent two years at <a href="/wiki/The_Kinkaid_School" title="The Kinkaid School">The Kinkaid School</a>, a <a href="/wiki/University-preparatory_school" title="University-preparatory school">prep school</a> in Houston.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup></p>
<p>Bush attended high school at <a href="/wiki/Phillips_Academy" title="Phillips Academy">Phillips Academy</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Boarding_school" title="Boarding school">boarding school</a> (then all-male) in <a href="/wiki/Andover,_Massachusetts" title="Andover, Massachusetts">Andover, Massachusetts</a>, where he played baseball and was the head cheerleader during his senior year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> He attended <a href="/wiki/Yale_University" title="Yale University">Yale University</a> from 1964 to 1968, graduating with a <a href="/wiki/Bachelor_of_Arts" title="Bachelor of Arts">Bachelor of Arts</a> degree in <a href="/wiki/History" title="History">history</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-whitehousebio_24-0"><a href="#cite_note-whitehousebio-24">[24]</a></sup> During this time, he was a cheerleader and a member of the <a href="/wiki/Delta_Kappa_Epsilon" title="Delta Kappa Epsilon">Delta Kappa Epsilon</a>, serving as the president of the fraternity during his senior year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup> Bush became a <a href="/wiki/List_of_Skull_and_Bones_members" title="List of Skull and Bones members">member</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Skull_and_Bones" title="Skull and Bones">Skull and Bones</a> society as a senior.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup> Bush was a <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">rugby union</a> player and was on Yale's 1st XV.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> He characterized himself as an average student.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup> His GPA during his first three years at Yale was 77, and he had a similar average under a nonnumeric rating system in his final year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup></p>
<p>Beginning in the fall of 1973, Bush attended <a href="/wiki/Harvard_Business_School" title="Harvard Business School">Harvard Business School</a>. He graduated in 1975 with an <a href="/wiki/Master_of_Business_Administration" title="Master of Business Administration">MBA</a> degree. He is the only U.S. president to have earned an MBA.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Family_and_personal_life">Family and personal life</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Bush_family" title="Bush family">Bush family</a></div>
<p>At a backyard barbecue in 1977, friends introduced him to <a href="/wiki/Laura_Bush" title="Laura Bush">Laura Welch</a>, a school teacher and librarian. After a three-month courtship, she accepted his marriage proposal and they wed on November 5 of that year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-readherlips_33-0"><a href="#cite_note-readherlips-33">[33]</a></sup> The couple settled in Midland, Texas. Bush left his family's <a href="/wiki/Episcopal_Church_(United_States)" title="Episcopal Church (United States)">Episcopal Church</a> to join his wife's <a href="/wiki/United_Methodist_Church" title="United Methodist Church">United Methodist Church</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-um_34-0"><a href="#cite_note-um-34">[34]</a></sup> On November 25, 1981, Laura Bush gave birth to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fraternal_twin" title="Fraternal twin">fraternal twin</a> daughters, <a href="/wiki/Barbara_Bush_(born_1981)" title="Barbara Bush (born 1981)">Barbara</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jenna_Bush_Hager" title="Jenna Bush Hager">Jenna</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-readherlips_33-1"><a href="#cite_note-readherlips-33">[33]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bush_daughters.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="296" data-file-width="428" height="152" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Bush_daughters.png/220px-Bush_daughters.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Bush_daughters.png/330px-Bush_daughters.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c5/Bush_daughters.png 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bush_daughters.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
George and <a href="/wiki/Laura_Bush" title="Laura Bush">Laura Bush</a> with their daughters <a href="/wiki/Jenna_Bush_Hager" title="Jenna Bush Hager">Jenna</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Barbara_Pierce_Bush_(1981)" title="Barbara Pierce Bush (1981)">Barbara</a>, 1990</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Prior to his marriage, Bush had multiple episodes of alcohol abuse.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Life-changing_35-0"><a href="#cite_note-Life-changing-35">[35]</a></sup> In one instance on September 4, 1976, he was arrested near his family's summer home in <a href="/wiki/Kennebunkport,_Maine" title="Kennebunkport, Maine">Kennebunkport, Maine</a> for driving under the influence of alcohol. He pleaded guilty, was fined $150, and had his Maine driver's license briefly suspended.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> Bush said his wife has had a stabilizing effect on his life,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-readherlips_33-2"><a href="#cite_note-readherlips-33">[33]</a></sup> and attributes his 1986 decision to give up alcohol to her influence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-turningpoint_37-0"><a href="#cite_note-turningpoint-37">[37]</a></sup> While Governor of Texas, Bush said of his wife, "I saw an elegant, beautiful woman who turned out not only to be elegant and beautiful, but very smart and willing to put up with my rough edges, and I must confess has smoothed them off over time."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-readherlips_33-3"><a href="#cite_note-readherlips-33">[33]</a></sup></p>
<p>Bush has been an avid reader throughout his adult life, preferring biographies and histories.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wp-cohen_38-0"><a href="#cite_note-wp-cohen-38">[38]</a></sup> During his time as president, Bush read the <a href="/wiki/Bible" title="Bible">Bible</a> daily.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bushmuseumofthebible_39-0"><a href="#cite_note-bushmuseumofthebible-39">[39]</a></sup> He also read 14 <a href="/wiki/Bibliography_of_Abraham_Lincoln" title="Bibliography of Abraham Lincoln">Lincoln biographies</a>, and during the last three years of his presidency, he reportedly read 186 books. Walt Harrington, a journalist, recalled seeing "books by <a href="/wiki/John_Fowles" title="John Fowles">John Fowles</a>, <a href="/wiki/F._Scott_Fitzgerald" title="F. Scott Fitzgerald">F. Scott Fitzgerald</a>, <a href="/wiki/James_Joyce" title="James Joyce">James Joyce</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Gore_Vidal" title="Gore Vidal">Gore Vidal</a> lying about, as well as biographies of <a href="/wiki/Willa_Cather" title="Willa Cather">Willa Cather</a> and <a href="/wiki/Queen_Victoria" title="Queen Victoria">Queen Victoria</a>" in his home when Bush was a Texas oilman. Other activities include cigar smoking and golf.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-harrington2011_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-harrington2011-40">[40]</a></sup> Since leaving the White House, Bush has also taken up oil painting.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military_career">Military career</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush_military_service_controversy" title="George W. Bush military service controversy">George W. Bush military service controversy</a></div>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Killian_documents_controversy" title="Killian documents controversy">Killian documents controversy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Killian_documents_authenticity_issues" title="Killian documents authenticity issues">Killian documents authenticity issues</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GW-Bush-in-uniform.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2076" data-file-width="1499" height="235" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/GW-Bush-in-uniform.jpg/170px-GW-Bush-in-uniform.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/GW-Bush-in-uniform.jpg/255px-GW-Bush-in-uniform.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/GW-Bush-in-uniform.jpg/340px-GW-Bush-in-uniform.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GW-Bush-in-uniform.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Lt. George W. Bush while in the <a href="/wiki/Texas_Air_National_Guard" title="Texas Air National Guard">Texas Air National Guard</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>In May 1968, Bush was commissioned into the <a href="/wiki/Texas_Air_National_Guard" title="Texas Air National Guard">Texas Air National Guard</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wpbushguardquestion_42-0"><a href="#cite_note-wpbushguardquestion-42">[42]</a></sup> After two years of active-duty service while training,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lardner19990728_43-0"><a href="#cite_note-lardner19990728-43">[43]</a></sup> he was assigned to Houston, flying <a href="/wiki/Convair" title="Convair">Convair</a> <a href="/wiki/Convair_F-102_Delta_Dagger" title="Convair F-102 Delta Dagger">F-102s</a> with the <a href="/wiki/147th_Reconnaissance_Wing" title="147th Reconnaissance Wing">147th Reconnaissance Wing</a> out of the <a href="/wiki/Ellington_Field_Joint_Reserve_Base" title="Ellington Field Joint Reserve Base">Ellington Field Joint Reserve Base</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wpbushguardquestion_42-1"><a href="#cite_note-wpbushguardquestion-42">[42]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> Critics, including former <a href="/wiki/Democratic_National_Committee" title="Democratic National Committee">Democratic National Committee</a> Chairman <a href="/wiki/Terry_McAuliffe" title="Terry McAuliffe">Terry McAuliffe</a>, have alleged that Bush was favorably treated due to his father's political standing as a member of the <a href="/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives" title="United States House of Representatives">House of Representatives</a>, citing his selection as a pilot despite his low pilot aptitude test scores and his irregular attendance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wpbushguardquestion_42-2"><a href="#cite_note-wpbushguardquestion-42">[42]</a></sup> In June 2005, the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Defense" title="United States Department of Defense">United States Department of Defense</a> released all the records of Bush's Texas Air National Guard service, which remain in its official archives.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USDoDbushrecords_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-USDoDbushrecords-45">[45]</a></sup></p>
<p>In late 1972 and early 1973, he <a href="/wiki/Battle_Assembly" title="Battle Assembly">drilled</a> with the <a href="/wiki/187th_Fighter_Wing" title="187th Fighter Wing">187th Fighter Wing</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Alabama_Air_National_Guard" title="Alabama Air National Guard">Alabama Air National Guard</a>. He had moved to <a href="/wiki/Montgomery,_Alabama" title="Montgomery, Alabama">Montgomery, Alabama</a>, to work on the unsuccessful U.S. Senate campaign of Republican <a href="/wiki/Winton_M._Blount" title="Winton M. Blount">Winton M. Blount</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup> In 1972, Bush was suspended from flying for failure to take a scheduled physical exam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup> He was honorably discharged from the <a href="/wiki/Air_Force_Reserve_Command" title="Air Force Reserve Command">Air Force Reserve</a> on November 21, 1974.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Business_career">Business career</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Professional_life_of_George_W._Bush" title="Professional life of George W. Bush">Professional life of George W. Bush</a></div>
<p>In 1977, Bush established <a href="/wiki/Arbusto_Energy" title="Arbusto Energy">Arbusto Energy</a>, a small oil exploration company, although it did not begin operations until the following year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lardner_50-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lardner-50">[50]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup> He later changed the name to Bush Exploration. In 1984, his company merged with the larger <a href="/wiki/Spectrum_7" title="Spectrum 7">Spectrum 7</a>, and Bush became chairman.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-msn_52-0"><a href="#cite_note-msn-52">[52]</a></sup> The company was hurt by decreased oil prices, and it folded into <a href="/wiki/HKN,_Inc." title="HKN, Inc.">HKN, Inc.</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-msn_52-1"><a href="#cite_note-msn-52">[52]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup> with Bush becoming a member of HKN's board of directors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-msn_52-2"><a href="#cite_note-msn-52">[52]</a></sup> Questions of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/George_W._Bush_insider_trading_allegations" title="George W. Bush insider trading allegations">possible insider trading</a> involving HKN arose, but a <a href="/wiki/U.S._Securities_and_Exchange_Commission" title="U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission">Securities and Exchange Commission</a> (SEC) investigation concluded that the information Bush had at the time of his stock sale was not sufficient to constitute insider trading.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-msn_52-3"><a href="#cite_note-msn-52">[52]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup></p>
<p>In April 1989, Bush arranged for a group of investors to purchase a controlling interest in the <a href="/wiki/Texas_Rangers_(baseball)" title="Texas Rangers (baseball)">Texas Rangers</a> baseball franchise for $89M and invested $500K himself to start. He then served as managing general partner for five years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TexRngrs_55-0"><a href="#cite_note-TexRngrs-55">[55]</a></sup> He actively led the team's projects and regularly attended its games, often choosing to sit in the open stands with fans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> Bush's sale of his shares in the Rangers in 1998 brought him over $15 million from his initial $800,000 investment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_political_involvement">Early political involvement</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:President_Bush_walks_up_the_South_Lawn_towards_the_Oval_Office_with_his_son,_George_W._Bush_-_NARA_-_186449.tif"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2384" data-file-width="1963" height="206" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/President_Bush_walks_up_the_South_Lawn_towards_the_Oval_Office_with_his_son%2C_George_W._Bush_-_NARA_-_186449.tif/lossy-page1-170px-President_Bush_walks_up_the_South_Lawn_towards_the_Oval_Office_with_his_son%2C_George_W._Bush_-_NARA_-_186449.tif.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/President_Bush_walks_up_the_South_Lawn_towards_the_Oval_Office_with_his_son%2C_George_W._Bush_-_NARA_-_186449.tif/lossy-page1-255px-President_Bush_walks_up_the_South_Lawn_towards_the_Oval_Office_with_his_son%2C_George_W._Bush_-_NARA_-_186449.tif.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/President_Bush_walks_up_the_South_Lawn_towards_the_Oval_Office_with_his_son%2C_George_W._Bush_-_NARA_-_186449.tif/lossy-page1-340px-President_Bush_walks_up_the_South_Lawn_towards_the_Oval_Office_with_his_son%2C_George_W._Bush_-_NARA_-_186449.tif.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:President_Bush_walks_up_the_South_Lawn_towards_the_Oval_Office_with_his_son,_George_W._Bush_-_NARA_-_186449.tif" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
George W. Bush with his father outside the White House, April 29, 1992</div>
</div>
</div>
<p><a href="/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections,_1978" title="United States House of Representatives elections, 1978">In 1978</a>, Bush ran for the <a href="/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives" title="United States House of Representatives">House of Representatives</a> from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Texas%27s_19th_congressional_district" title="Texas's 19th congressional district">Texas's 19th congressional district</a>. The retiring member, <a href="/wiki/George_H._Mahon" title="George H. Mahon">George H. Mahon</a>, had held the district for the Democratic Party since 1935. Bush's opponent, <a href="/wiki/Kent_Hance" title="Kent Hance">Kent Hance</a>, portrayed him as out of touch with rural Texans, and Bush lost the election with 46.8 percent of the vote to Hance's 53.2 percent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NewsMine_58-0"><a href="#cite_note-NewsMine-58">[58]</a></sup></p>
<p>Bush and his family moved to Washington, D.C., in 1988 to work on his father's campaign for the U.S. presidency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup> He served as a campaign advisor and liaison to the media, and assisted his father by campaigning across the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-msn_52-4"><a href="#cite_note-msn-52">[52]</a></sup> In December 1991, Bush was one of seven people named by his father to run his father's 1992 presidential re-election campaign, as a "campaign advisor".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> The previous month, his father had asked him to tell White House chief of staff <a href="/wiki/John_H._Sununu" title="John H. Sununu">John H. Sununu</a> that he should resign.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span id="Governor_of_Texas_(1995–2000)"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Governor_of_Texas_.281995.E2.80.932000.29">Governor of Texas (1995–2000)</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Governorship_of_George_W._Bush" title="Governorship of George W. Bush">Governorship of George W. Bush</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:George_H._W._Bush,_Laura_Bush,_George_W._Bush_1997.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="400" data-file-width="600" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/George_H._W._Bush%2C_Laura_Bush%2C_George_W._Bush_1997.jpg/220px-George_H._W._Bush%2C_Laura_Bush%2C_George_W._Bush_1997.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/George_H._W._Bush%2C_Laura_Bush%2C_George_W._Bush_1997.jpg/330px-George_H._W._Bush%2C_Laura_Bush%2C_George_W._Bush_1997.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/George_H._W._Bush%2C_Laura_Bush%2C_George_W._Bush_1997.jpg/440px-George_H._W._Bush%2C_Laura_Bush%2C_George_W._Bush_1997.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:George_H._W._Bush,_Laura_Bush,_George_W._Bush_1997.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Governor Bush (right) with father, former president <a href="/wiki/George_H._W._Bush" title="George H. W. Bush">George H. W. Bush</a> and wife, Laura, in 1997</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Bush declared his candidacy for the <a href="/wiki/Texas_gubernatorial_election,_1994" title="Texas gubernatorial election, 1994">1994 Texas gubernatorial election</a> at the same time that his brother Jeb <a href="/wiki/Florida_gubernatorial_election,_1994" title="Florida gubernatorial election, 1994">sought the governorship of Florida</a>. His campaign focused on four themes: welfare reform, <a href="/wiki/Tort_reform" title="Tort reform">tort reform</a>, crime reduction, and education improvement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-msn_52-5"><a href="#cite_note-msn-52">[52]</a></sup> Bush's campaign advisers were <a href="/wiki/Karen_Hughes" title="Karen Hughes">Karen Hughes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Joe_Allbaugh" title="Joe Allbaugh">Joe Allbaugh</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Karl_Rove" title="Karl Rove">Karl Rove</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SlaterBrain_63-0"><a href="#cite_note-SlaterBrain-63">[63]</a></sup></p>
<p>After easily winning the Republican primary, Bush faced popular Democratic incumbent Governor <a href="/wiki/Ann_Richards" title="Ann Richards">Ann Richards</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-msn_52-6"><a href="#cite_note-msn-52">[52]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-telegraph_64-0"><a href="#cite_note-telegraph-64">[64]</a></sup> In the course of the campaign, Bush pledged to sign a bill allowing Texans to obtain <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Concealed_carry_permit" title="Concealed carry permit">permits to carry concealed weapons</a>. Richards had vetoed the bill, but Bush signed it into law after he became governor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-concealed_carry_65-0"><a href="#cite_note-concealed_carry-65">[65]</a></sup> According to <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Atlantic_Monthly" title="The Atlantic Monthly">The Atlantic Monthly</a></i>, the race "featured a rumor that she was a lesbian, along with a rare instance of such a tactic's making it into the public record – when a regional chairman of the Bush campaign allowed himself, perhaps inadvertently, to be quoted criticizing Richards for 'appointing avowed <a href="/wiki/LGBT_social_movements" title="LGBT social movements">homosexual activists</a>' to state jobs".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup> <i>The Atlantic</i>, and others, connected the lesbian rumor to Karl Rove,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup> but Rove denied being involved.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> Bush won the general election with 53.5 percent against Richards' 45.9 percent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup></p>
<p>Bush used a budget surplus to push through Texas's largest tax-cut, $2 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SlaterBrain_63-1"><a href="#cite_note-SlaterBrain-63">[63]</a></sup> He extended government funding for organizations providing education of the dangers of alcohol and drug use and abuse, and helping to reduce <a href="/wiki/Domestic_violence" title="Domestic violence">domestic violence</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup> Critics contended that during his tenure, Texas ranked near the bottom in environmental evaluations. Supporters pointed to his efforts to raise the salaries of teachers and improve educational test scores.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-msn_52-7"><a href="#cite_note-msn-52">[52]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 1999, Bush signed a law that required electric retailers to buy a <a href="/wiki/Renewable_portfolio_standard" title="Renewable portfolio standard">certain amount of energy from renewable sources</a> (RPS),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-txlaw_71-0"><a href="#cite_note-txlaw-71">[71]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup> which helped <a href="/wiki/Wind_power_in_Texas" title="Wind power in Texas">Texas</a> eventually become the <a href="/wiki/Wind_power_in_the_United_States" title="Wind power in the United States">leading producer</a> of <a href="/wiki/Wind_power" title="Wind power">wind powered</a> electricity in the U.S.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-txwind_74-0"><a href="#cite_note-txwind-74">[74]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mighty_wind_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-mighty_wind-75">[75]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sector_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-sector-76">[76]</a></sup></p>
<p>In <a href="/wiki/Texas_gubernatorial_election,_1998" title="Texas gubernatorial election, 1998">1998</a>, Bush won re-election with a record<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-msn_52-8"><a href="#cite_note-msn-52">[52]</a></sup> 69 percent of the vote.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> He became the first governor in Texas history to be elected to two consecutive four-year terms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-msn_52-9"><a href="#cite_note-msn-52">[52]</a></sup> For most of Texas history, governors served two-year terms; a <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_amendment" title="Constitutional amendment">constitutional amendment</a> extended those terms to four years starting in 1975.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup> In his second term, Bush promoted faith-based organizations and enjoyed high approval ratings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-msn_52-10"><a href="#cite_note-msn-52">[52]</a></sup> He proclaimed June 10, 2000 to be <a href="/wiki/Jesus_Day" title="Jesus Day">Jesus Day</a> in Texas, a day on which he "urge[d] all Texans to answer the call to serve those in need".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup></p>
<p>Throughout Bush's first term, national attention focused on him as a potential future presidential candidate. Following his re-election, speculation soared.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-msn_52-11"><a href="#cite_note-msn-52">[52]</a></sup> Within a year, he decided to seek the 2000 Republican presidential nomination.</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Presidential_campaigns">Presidential campaigns</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2000_presidential_candidacy">2000 presidential candidacy</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2000" title="United States presidential election, 2000">United States presidential election, 2000</a></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Primary">Primary</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:George_W._Bush_in_Concord,_New_Hampshire_signing_papers_for_presidential_run.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="825" data-file-width="1024" height="177" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/George_W._Bush_in_Concord%2C_New_Hampshire_signing_papers_for_presidential_run.jpg/220px-George_W._Bush_in_Concord%2C_New_Hampshire_signing_papers_for_presidential_run.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/George_W._Bush_in_Concord%2C_New_Hampshire_signing_papers_for_presidential_run.jpg/330px-George_W._Bush_in_Concord%2C_New_Hampshire_signing_papers_for_presidential_run.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/George_W._Bush_in_Concord%2C_New_Hampshire_signing_papers_for_presidential_run.jpg/440px-George_W._Bush_in_Concord%2C_New_Hampshire_signing_papers_for_presidential_run.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:George_W._Bush_in_Concord,_New_Hampshire_signing_papers_for_presidential_run.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
George W. Bush in Concord, New Hampshire signing to be a candidate for president</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Lame duck incumbent president <a href="/wiki/Bill_Clinton" title="Bill Clinton">Bill Clinton</a> was a Democrat, and the field for nomination for President of both parties was wide open. Bush was governor of Texas in June 1999 when he announced his candidacy for President of the United States. He entered a large field of hopefuls for the Republican Party presidential nomination that included <a href="/wiki/John_McCain" title="John McCain">John McCain</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alan_Keyes" title="Alan Keyes">Alan Keyes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Steve_Forbes" title="Steve Forbes">Steve Forbes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gary_Bauer" title="Gary Bauer">Gary Bauer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Orrin_Hatch" title="Orrin Hatch">Orrin Hatch</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_Dole" title="Elizabeth Dole">Elizabeth Dole</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dan_Quayle" title="Dan Quayle">Dan Quayle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pat_Buchanan" title="Pat Buchanan">Pat Buchanan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lamar_Alexander" title="Lamar Alexander">Lamar Alexander</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Kasich" title="John Kasich">John Kasich</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bob_Smith_(American_politician)" title="Bob Smith (American politician)">Bob Smith</a>.</p>
<p>Bush portrayed himself as a <a href="/wiki/Compassionate_conservatism" title="Compassionate conservatism">compassionate conservative</a>, implying he was more centrist than other Republicans. He campaigned on a platform that included bringing integrity and honor back to the White House, increasing the size of the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces" title="United States Armed Forces">United States Armed Forces</a>, cutting taxes, improving education, and aiding minorities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-msn_52-12"><a href="#cite_note-msn-52">[52]</a></sup> By early 2000, the race had centered on Bush and McCain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-msn_52-13"><a href="#cite_note-msn-52">[52]</a></sup></p>
<p>Bush won the <a href="/wiki/Iowa_caucuses" title="Iowa caucuses">Iowa caucuses</a>, and although he was heavily favored to win the <a href="/wiki/New_Hampshire_primary" title="New Hampshire primary">New Hampshire primary</a>, he trailed McCain by 19 percent and lost that primary. Despite this, Bush regained momentum, and according to political observers, he effectively became the front runner after the <a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_presidential_primaries,_2000" title="Republican Party presidential primaries, 2000">South Carolina primary</a>—which according to <i><a href="/wiki/The_Boston_Globe" title="The Boston Globe">The Boston Globe</a></i>—made history for his campaign's negativity. <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i> described it as a <a href="/wiki/Smear_campaign" title="Smear campaign">smear campaign</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-anatomy_80-0"><a href="#cite_note-anatomy-80">[80]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="General_election">General election</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:277px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ElectoralCollege2000.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="593" data-file-width="1020" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/ElectoralCollege2000.svg/275px-ElectoralCollege2000.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/ElectoralCollege2000.svg/413px-ElectoralCollege2000.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/ElectoralCollege2000.svg/550px-ElectoralCollege2000.svg.png 2x" width="275"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ElectoralCollege2000.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
2000 electoral vote results.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>On July 25, 2000, Bush surprised some observers when he selected <a href="/wiki/Dick_Cheney" title="Dick Cheney">Dick Cheney</a>—a former <a href="/wiki/White_House_Chief_of_Staff" title="White House Chief of Staff">White House Chief of Staff</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives" title="United States House of Representatives">U.S. Representative</a>, and <a href="/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_Defense" title="United States Secretary of Defense">Secretary of Defense</a>—to be his <a href="/wiki/Running_mate" title="Running mate">running mate</a>. At the time, Cheney was serving as head of Bush's Vice-Presidential search committee. Soon after at the <a href="/wiki/2000_Republican_National_Convention" title="2000 Republican National Convention">2000 Republican National Convention</a>, Bush and Cheney were officially nominated by the Republican Party.</p>
<p>Bush continued to campaign across the country and touted his record as governor of Texas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-msn_52-14"><a href="#cite_note-msn-52">[52]</a></sup> During his campaign, Bush criticized his Democratic opponent, incumbent Vice President <a href="/wiki/Al_Gore" title="Al Gore">Al Gore</a>, over <a href="/wiki/Gun_law_in_the_United_States" title="Gun law in the United States">gun control</a> and taxation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup></p>
<p>When the election returns were tallied on November 7, Bush had won 29 states, including Florida. The closeness of the Florida outcome led to a <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election_in_Florida,_2000" title="United States presidential election in Florida, 2000">recount</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-msn_52-15"><a href="#cite_note-msn-52">[52]</a></sup> The initial recount also went to Bush, but the outcome was tied up in lower courts for a month until eventually reaching the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States" title="Supreme Court of the United States">U.S. Supreme Court</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup> On December 9, in the controversial <i><a href="/wiki/Bush_v._Gore" title="Bush v. Gore">Bush v. Gore</a></i> ruling,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup> the Court reversed a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Florida_Supreme_Court" title="Florida Supreme Court">Florida Supreme Court</a> decision that had ordered a third count, and stopped an ordered statewide hand recount based on the argument that the use of different standards among Florida's counties violated the <a href="/wiki/Equal_Protection_Clause" title="Equal Protection Clause">Equal Protection Clause</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Fourteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution" title="Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution">Fourteenth Amendment</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-msn_52-16"><a href="#cite_note-msn-52">[52]</a></sup> The machine recount showed that Bush had won the Florida vote by a margin of 537 votes out of six million cast.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2000results_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-2000results-86">[86]</a></sup> Although he had received 543,895 fewer individual nationwide votes than Gore, Bush won the election, receiving 271 <a href="/wiki/Electoral_College_(United_States)" title="Electoral College (United States)">electoral votes</a> to Gore's 266 (Gore's statewide victories had electoral votes tallying 267; however, one of Gore's pledged electors abstained, rendering the official tally at 266). Bush was the first person to win an American presidential election with fewer popular votes than another candidate since <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Harrison" title="Benjamin Harrison">Benjamin Harrison</a> in 1888.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2000results_86-1"><a href="#cite_note-2000results-86">[86]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2004_presidential_candidacy">2004 presidential candidacy</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2004" title="United States presidential election, 2004">United States presidential election, 2004</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bush_43_10-19-04_Stpete.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1024" data-file-width="757" height="230" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Bush_43_10-19-04_Stpete.jpg/170px-Bush_43_10-19-04_Stpete.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Bush_43_10-19-04_Stpete.jpg/255px-Bush_43_10-19-04_Stpete.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Bush_43_10-19-04_Stpete.jpg/340px-Bush_43_10-19-04_Stpete.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bush_43_10-19-04_Stpete.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
George W. Bush speaks at a campaign rally in 2004</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:277px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ElectoralCollege2004.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="593" data-file-width="1020" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/ElectoralCollege2004.svg/275px-ElectoralCollege2004.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/ElectoralCollege2004.svg/413px-ElectoralCollege2004.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/ElectoralCollege2004.svg/550px-ElectoralCollege2004.svg.png 2x" width="275"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ElectoralCollege2004.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
2004 electoral vote results.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>In his 2004 bid for re-election, Bush commanded broad support in the Republican Party and did not encounter a primary challenge. He appointed <a href="/wiki/Ken_Mehlman" title="Ken Mehlman">Ken Mehlman</a> as campaign manager, and <a href="/wiki/Karl_Rove" title="Karl Rove">Karl Rove</a> devised a political strategy .<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup> Bush and the Republican platform emphasized a strong commitment to the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-platform04_88-0"><a href="#cite_note-platform04-88">[88]</a></sup> support for the <a href="/wiki/Patriot_Act" title="Patriot Act">USA PATRIOT Act</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup> a renewed shift in policy for constitutional amendments banning abortion and <a href="/wiki/Same-sex_marriage" title="Same-sex marriage">same-sex marriage</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-platform04_88-1"><a href="#cite_note-platform04-88">[88]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup> reforming <a href="/wiki/Social_Security_(United_States)" title="Social Security (United States)">Social Security</a> to create private investment accounts,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-platform04_88-2"><a href="#cite_note-platform04-88">[88]</a></sup> creation of an <a href="/wiki/Ownership_society" title="Ownership society">ownership society</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-platform04_88-3"><a href="#cite_note-platform04-88">[88]</a></sup> and opposing mandatory carbon emissions controls.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup> Bush also called for the implementation of a <a href="/wiki/Guest_worker_program" title="Guest worker program">guest worker program</a> for immigrants,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-platform04_88-4"><a href="#cite_note-platform04-88">[88]</a></sup> which was criticized by conservatives.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup></p>
<p>The Bush campaign advertised across the U.S. against Democratic candidates, including Bush's emerging opponent, Massachusetts Senator <a href="/wiki/John_Kerry" title="John Kerry">John Kerry</a>. Kerry and other Democrats attacked Bush on the <a href="/wiki/Iraq_War" title="Iraq War">Iraq War</a>, and accused him of failing to stimulate the economy and job growth. The Bush campaign portrayed Kerry as a staunch <a href="/wiki/Liberalism_in_the_United_States" title="Liberalism in the United States">liberal</a> who would raise taxes and increase the size of government. The Bush campaign continuously criticized Kerry's seemingly contradictory statements on the war in Iraq,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-msn_52-17"><a href="#cite_note-msn-52">[52]</a></sup> and argued that Kerry lacked the decisiveness and vision necessary for success in the War on Terror.</p>
<p>In the election, Bush carried 31 of 50 states, receiving a total of 286 <a href="/wiki/Electoral_College_(United_States)" title="Electoral College (United States)">electoral votes</a>. He won an absolute majority of the popular vote (50.7 percent to his opponent's 48.3 percent).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16_years_93-0"><a href="#cite_note-16_years-93">[93]</a></sup> Bush's father George H.W. Bush was the previous president who won an absolute majority of the popular vote; he accomplished that feat in the 1988 election. Additionally, it was the first time since <a href="/wiki/Herbert_Hoover" title="Herbert Hoover">Herbert Hoover</a>'s <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1928" title="United States presidential election, 1928">election in 1928</a> that a Republican president was elected alongside re-elected Republican majorities in both Houses of Congress.</p>
<h2><span id="Presidency_(2001–2009)"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Presidency_.282001.E2.80.932009.29">Presidency (2001–2009)</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_George_W._Bush" title="Presidency of George W. Bush">Presidency of George W. Bush</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Defense.gov_News_Photo_010917-D-9880W-034.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1930" data-file-width="2510" height="169" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Defense.gov_News_Photo_010917-D-9880W-034.jpg/220px-Defense.gov_News_Photo_010917-D-9880W-034.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Defense.gov_News_Photo_010917-D-9880W-034.jpg/330px-Defense.gov_News_Photo_010917-D-9880W-034.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Defense.gov_News_Photo_010917-D-9880W-034.jpg/440px-Defense.gov_News_Photo_010917-D-9880W-034.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Defense.gov_News_Photo_010917-D-9880W-034.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
President Bush addressing the media at the Pentagon, September 17, 2001</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Bush had originally outlined an ambitious domestic agenda, but his priorities were significantly altered following the <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup> Wars were waged in Afghanistan and Iraq, and there were significant domestic debates regarding immigration, healthcare, Social Security, economic policy, and treatment of terrorist detainees. Over an eight-year period, Bush's once-high approval ratings<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gallup_high_95-0"><a href="#cite_note-gallup_high-95">[95]</a></sup> steadily declined, while his disapproval numbers increased significantly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wapo_ratings_96-0"><a href="#cite_note-wapo_ratings-96">[96]</a></sup> In 2007, the United States entered the longest post-World War II recession.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-longest1_97-0"><a href="#cite_note-longest1-97">[97]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Domestic_policy">Domestic policy</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Domestic_policy_of_the_George_W._Bush_administration" title="Domestic policy of the George W. Bush administration">Domestic policy of the George W. Bush administration</a></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Economic_policy">Economic policy</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economic_policy_of_the_George_W._Bush_administration" title="Economic policy of the George W. Bush administration">Economic policy of the George W. Bush administration</a></div>
<p>Bush took office during a period of economic recession in the wake of the bursting of the <a href="/wiki/Dot-com_bubble" title="Dot-com bubble">dot-com bubble</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup> The terrorist attacks also impacted the economy. His administration increased federal <a href="/wiki/Government_spending" title="Government spending">government spending</a> from $1.789 trillion to $2.983 trillion (60 percent) while revenues increased from $2.025 trillion to $2.524 trillion (from 2000 to 2008). Individual income tax revenues increased by 14 percent, corporate tax revenues by 50 percent, customs and duties by 40 percent. Discretionary defense spending was increased by 107 percent, discretionary domestic spending by 62 percent, Medicare spending by 131 percent, social security by 51 percent, and income security spending by 130 percent. Cyclically adjusted, revenues rose by 35 percent and spending by 65 percent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bushtaxcuts.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="425" height="240" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Bushtaxcuts.jpg/170px-Bushtaxcuts.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Bushtaxcuts.jpg/255px-Bushtaxcuts.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Bushtaxcuts.jpg/340px-Bushtaxcuts.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bushtaxcuts.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
President Bush signing a $1.35 trillion <a href="/wiki/Economic_Growth_and_Tax_Relief_Reconciliation_Act_of_2001" title="Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001">tax cut into law</a>, June 7, 2001</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The increase in spending was more than under any predecessor since <a href="/wiki/Lyndon_B._Johnson" title="Lyndon B. Johnson">Lyndon B. Johnson</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup> The number of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Economic_regulation" title="Economic regulation">economic regulation</a> governmental workers increased by 91,196.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bushregulation_101-0"><a href="#cite_note-bushregulation-101">[101]</a></sup></p>
<p>The surplus in fiscal year 2000 was $237 billion—the third consecutive surplus and the largest surplus ever.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-omb_102-0"><a href="#cite_note-omb-102">[102]</a></sup> In 2001, Bush's budget estimated that there would be a $5.6 trillion surplus over the next ten years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup> Facing congressional opposition, Bush held townhall style meetings across the U.S. in order to increase public support for his plan for a $1.35 trillion <a href="/wiki/Economic_Growth_and_Tax_Relief_Reconciliation_Act_of_2001" title="Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001">tax cut program</a>—one of the largest tax cuts in U.S. history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-msn_52-18"><a href="#cite_note-msn-52">[52]</a></sup> Bush argued that unspent government funds should be returned to taxpayers, saying "the surplus is not the government's money. The surplus is the people's money."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-msn_52-19"><a href="#cite_note-msn-52">[52]</a></sup> Federal Reserve chairman <a href="/wiki/Alan_Greenspan" title="Alan Greenspan">Alan Greenspan</a> warned of a recession and Bush stated that a tax cut would stimulate the economy and create jobs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup> Treasury Secretary <a href="/wiki/Paul_H._O%27Neill" title="Paul H. O'Neill">Paul H. O'Neill</a>, opposed some of the tax cuts on the basis that they would contribute to budget deficits and undermine <a href="/wiki/Social_Security_(United_States)" title="Social Security (United States)">Social Security</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup> O'Neill disputes the claim, made in Bush's book <i>Decision Points</i>, that he never openly disagreed with him on planned tax cuts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup> By 2003, the economy showed signs of improvement, though job growth remained stagnant.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-msn_52-20"><a href="#cite_note-msn-52">[52]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jobs_and_Growth_Tax_Relief_Reconciliation_Act_of_2003" title="Jobs and Growth Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2003">Another tax cut program</a> was passed that year.</p>
<p>During the 2001 to 2008 years, GDP grew at an average annual rate of 2.125 percent,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup> less than for past business cycles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Price_.26_Ratner_108-0"><a href="#cite_note-Price_.26_Ratner-108">[108]</a></sup></p>
<p>Bush entered office with the <a href="/wiki/Dow_Jones_Industrial_Average" title="Dow Jones Industrial Average">Dow Jones Industrial Average</a> at 10,587, and the average peaked in October 2007 at over 14,000. When Bush left office, the average was at 7,949, one of the lowest levels of his presidency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Deficits_vs._Debt_Increases_-_2009.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="720" data-file-width="960" height="225" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Deficits_vs._Debt_Increases_-_2009.png/300px-Deficits_vs._Debt_Increases_-_2009.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Deficits_vs._Debt_Increases_-_2009.png/450px-Deficits_vs._Debt_Increases_-_2009.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Deficits_vs._Debt_Increases_-_2009.png/600px-Deficits_vs._Debt_Increases_-_2009.png 2x" width="300"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Deficits_vs._Debt_Increases_-_2009.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/United_States_federal_budget" title="United States federal budget">Deficit</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_public_debt" title="United States public debt">debt</a> increases 2001–2009. Gross debt has increased over $500 billion each year since FY2003.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Unemployment originally rose from 4.2 percent in January 2001 to 6.3 percent in June 2003, but subsequently dropped to 4.5 percent as of July 2007.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup> Adjusted for inflation, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Median_household_income" title="Median household income">median household income</a> dropped by $1,175 between 2000 and 2007,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup> while Professor Ken Homa of <a href="/wiki/Georgetown_University" title="Georgetown University">Georgetown University</a> has noted that "Median real after-tax household income went up 2 percent".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup> The poverty rate increased from 11.3 percent in 2000 to 12.3 percent in 2006 after peaking at 12.7 percent in 2004.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup> By October 2008, due to increases in spending,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/National_debt_of_the_United_States" title="National debt of the United States">national debt</a> had risen to $11.3 trillion,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup> an increase of over 100 percent from 2000 when the debt was only $5.6 trillion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup> Most debt was accumulated as a result of what became known as the "<a href="/wiki/Bush_tax_cuts" title="Bush tax cuts">Bush tax cuts</a>" and increased national security spending.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup> In March 2006, then-Senator <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> said when he voted against raising the <a href="/wiki/United_States_debt_ceiling" title="United States debt ceiling">debt ceiling</a>: "The fact that we are here today to debate raising America's debt limit is a sign of leadership failure."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup> By the end of Bush's presidency, unemployment climbed to 7.2 percent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup></p>
<p>In December 2007, the United States entered the longest post–<a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> recession,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-longest1_97-1"><a href="#cite_note-longest1-97">[97]</a></sup> which included a <a href="/wiki/United_States_housing_market_correction" title="United States housing market correction">housing market correction</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Subprime_mortgage_crisis" title="Subprime mortgage crisis">subprime mortgage crisis</a>, <a href="/wiki/2000s_energy_crisis" title="2000s energy crisis">soaring oil prices</a>, and a declining dollar value.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup> In February, 63,000 jobs were lost, a five-year record.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup> To aid with the situation, Bush signed a $170 billion economic stimulus package which was intended to improve the economic situation by sending tax rebate checks to many Americans and providing tax breaks for struggling businesses. The Bush administration pushed for significantly increased regulation of <a href="/wiki/Fannie_Mae" title="Fannie Mae">Fannie Mae</a> and <a href="/wiki/Freddie_Mac" title="Freddie Mac">Freddie Mac</a> in 2003,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup> and after two years, the regulations passed the House but died in the Senate. Many Republican senators, as well as influential members of the Bush Administration, feared that the agency created by these regulations would merely be mimicking the private sector's risky practices.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-admin_crisis_126-0"><a href="#cite_note-admin_crisis-126">[126]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup> In September 2008, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%9308" title="Financial crisis of 2007–08">the crisis became much more serious</a> beginning with the government takeover of <a href="/wiki/Federal_takeover_of_Fannie_Mae_and_Freddie_Mac" title="Federal takeover of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac">Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac</a> followed by the collapse of <a href="/wiki/Lehman_Brothers" title="Lehman Brothers">Lehman Brothers</a> and a federal bailout of <a href="/wiki/American_International_Group" title="American International Group">American International Group</a> for $85 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup></p>
<p>Many economists and world governments determined that the situation became the worst financial crisis since the <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression" title="Great Depression">Great Depression</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup> Additional regulation over the housing market would have been beneficial, according to former Federal Reserve chairman <a href="/wiki/Alan_Greenspan" title="Alan Greenspan">Alan Greenspan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup> Bush, meanwhile, proposed a <a href="/wiki/Emergency_Economic_Stabilization_Act_of_2008" title="Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008">financial rescue plan</a> to buy back a large portion of the U.S. mortgage market.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup> Vince Reinhardt, a former Federal Reserve economist now at the <a href="/wiki/American_Enterprise_Institute" title="American Enterprise Institute">American Enterprise Institute</a>, said "it would have helped for the Bush administration to empower the folks at Treasury and the Federal Reserve and the comptroller of the currency and the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Deposit_Insurance_Corporation" title="Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation">FDIC</a> to look at these issues more closely", and additionally, that it would have helped "for Congress to have held hearings".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-admin_crisis_126-1"><a href="#cite_note-admin_crisis-126">[126]</a></sup></p>
<p>In November 2008, over 500,000 jobs were lost, which marked the largest loss of jobs in the United States in 34 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Bureau_of_Labor_Statistics" title="Bureau of Labor Statistics">Bureau of Labor Statistics</a> reported that in the last four months of 2008, 1.9 million jobs were lost.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> By the end of 2008, the U.S. had lost a total of 2.6 million jobs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Education_and_health">Education and health</span></h4>
<p>Bush undertook a number of educational agendas, such as increasing the funding for the <a href="/wiki/National_Science_Foundation" title="National Science Foundation">National Science Foundation</a> and <a href="/wiki/National_Institutes_of_Health" title="National Institutes of Health">National Institutes of Health</a> in his first years of office, and creating education programs to strengthen the grounding in science and mathematics for American high school students. Funding for the NIH was cut in 2006, the first such cut in 36 years, due to rising inflation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:No_Child_Left_Behind_Act.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="337" data-file-width="515" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/No_Child_Left_Behind_Act.jpg/220px-No_Child_Left_Behind_Act.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/No_Child_Left_Behind_Act.jpg/330px-No_Child_Left_Behind_Act.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/No_Child_Left_Behind_Act.jpg/440px-No_Child_Left_Behind_Act.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:No_Child_Left_Behind_Act.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
President Bush signing the <a href="/wiki/No_Child_Left_Behind_Act" title="No Child Left Behind Act">No Child Left Behind Act</a> into law, January 8, 2002</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>One of the administration's early major initiatives was the <a href="/wiki/No_Child_Left_Behind_Act" title="No Child Left Behind Act">No Child Left Behind Act</a>, which aimed to measure and close the gap between rich and poor student performance, provide options to parents with students in low-performing schools, and target more federal funding to low-income schools.
