This landmark education initiative passed with broad bipartisan support, including that of Senator <a href="/wiki/Ted_Kennedy" title="Ted Kennedy">Ted Kennedy</a> of <a href="/wiki/Massachusetts" title="Massachusetts">Massachusetts</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup> It was signed into law by Bush in early 2002.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[138]</a></sup> Many contend that the initiative has been successful, as cited by the fact that students in the U.S. have performed significantly better on state reading and math tests since Bush signed "No Child Left Behind" into law.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup> Critics argue that it is underfunded<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup> and that NCLBA's focus on "high-stakes testing" and quantitative outcomes is counterproductive.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup></p>
<p>After being re-elected, Bush signed into law a <a href="/wiki/Medicare_(United_States)" title="Medicare (United States)">Medicare</a> drug benefit program that, according to <a href="/wiki/Jan_Crawford" title="Jan Crawford">Jan Crawford</a>, resulted in "the greatest expansion in America's <a href="/wiki/Welfare_state" title="Welfare state">welfare state</a> in forty years;" the bill's costs approached $7 trillion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup> In 2007, Bush opposed and vetoed <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/State_Children%27s_Health_Insurance_Program" title="State Children's Health Insurance Program">State Children's Health Insurance Program</a> (SCHIP) legislation, which was added by the Democrats onto a war funding bill and passed by Congress. The SCHIP legislation would have significantly expanded federally funded health care benefits and plans to children of some low-income families from about six million to ten million children. It was to be funded by an increase in the cigarette tax.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup> Bush viewed the legislation as a move toward <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Socialized_health_care" title="Socialized health care">socialized health care</a>, and asserted that the program could benefit families making as much as $83,000 per year who did not need the help.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Social_services_and_Social_Security">Social services and Social Security</span></h4>
<p>Following Republican efforts to pass the <a href="/wiki/Medicare_Prescription_Drug,_Improvement,_and_Modernization_Act" title="Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act">Medicare Act of 2003</a>, Bush signed the bill, which included major changes to the <a href="/wiki/Medicare_(United_States)" title="Medicare (United States)">Medicare</a> program by providing beneficiaries with some assistance in paying for prescription drugs, while relying on private insurance for the delivery of benefits.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup> The retired persons lobby group <a href="/wiki/AARP" title="AARP">AARP</a> worked with the Bush Administration on the program and gave their endorsement. Bush said the law, estimated to cost $400 billion over the first ten years, would give the elderly "better choices and more control over their health care".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:President_George_W._Bush_discussing_Social_Security.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="329" data-file-width="514" height="141" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/President_George_W._Bush_discussing_Social_Security.jpg/220px-President_George_W._Bush_discussing_Social_Security.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/President_George_W._Bush_discussing_Social_Security.jpg/330px-President_George_W._Bush_discussing_Social_Security.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/President_George_W._Bush_discussing_Social_Security.jpg/440px-President_George_W._Bush_discussing_Social_Security.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:President_George_W._Bush_discussing_Social_Security.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
President Bush discussing Social Security reform at the Lake Nona YMCA Family Center in Orlando, Florida, March 18, 2005</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Bush began his second term by outlining a major initiative to "<a href="/wiki/Social_Security_debate_in_the_United_States" title="Social Security debate in the United States">reform</a>" Social Security,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ss-msnbc_147-0"><a href="#cite_note-ss-msnbc-147">[147]</a></sup> which was facing record deficit projections beginning in 2005. Bush made it the centerpiece of his domestic agenda despite opposition from some in the U.S. Congress.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ss-msnbc_147-1"><a href="#cite_note-ss-msnbc-147">[147]</a></sup> In his <a href="/wiki/2005_State_of_the_Union_Address" title="2005 State of the Union Address">2005 State of the Union Address</a>, Bush discussed the potential impending bankruptcy of the program and outlined his new program, which included partial privatization of the system, personal Social Security accounts, and options to permit Americans to divert a portion of their Social Security tax (<a href="/wiki/Federal_Insurance_Contributions_Act_tax" title="Federal Insurance Contributions Act tax">FICA</a>) into secured investments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ss-msnbc_147-2"><a href="#cite_note-ss-msnbc-147">[147]</a></sup> Democrats opposed the proposal to partially privatize the system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ss-msnbc_147-3"><a href="#cite_note-ss-msnbc-147">[147]</a></sup></p>
<p>Bush embarked on a 60-day national tour, campaigning for his initiative in media events known as "Conversations on Social Security", in an attempt to gain public support.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup> Nevertheless, public support for the proposal declined<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup> and the House Republican leadership decided not to put Social Security reform on the priority list for the remainder of their 2005 legislative agenda.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup> The proposal's legislative prospects were further diminished by the fall of 2005 political fallout from <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Katrina" title="Hurricane Katrina">Hurricane Katrina</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup> After the Democrats gained control of both houses of Congress as a result of the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Senate_elections,_2006" title="United States Senate elections, 2006">2006 midterm elections</a>, there was no prospect of further congressional action on the Bush proposal for the remainder of his term in office.</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Environmental_policies">Environmental policies</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Domestic_policy_of_the_George_W._Bush_administration#Environment" title="Domestic policy of the George W. Bush administration">Domestic policy of the George W. Bush administration § Environment</a></div>
<p>Upon taking office in 2001, Bush stated his opposition to the <a href="/wiki/Kyoto_Protocol" title="Kyoto Protocol">Kyoto Protocol</a>, an amendment to the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Framework_Convention_on_Climate_Change" title="United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change">United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change</a> which seeks to impose mandatory targets for reducing <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gas" title="Greenhouse gas">greenhouse gas</a> emissions, citing that the treaty exempted 80 percent of the world's population<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup> and would have cost tens of billions of dollars per year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup> He also cited that the Senate had voted 95–0 in 1997 on a resolution expressing its disapproval of the protocol.</p>
<p>In May 2001, Bush signed an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Executive_order" title="Executive order">executive order</a> to create an inter-agency task force to streamline energy projects,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eo13212_154-0"><a href="#cite_note-eo13212-154">[154]</a></sup> and later signed two other executive orders to tackle environmental issues.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sovaWater_155-0"><a href="#cite_note-sovaWater-155">[155]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 2002, Bush announced the <a href="/wiki/Clear_Skies_Act_of_2003" title="Clear Skies Act of 2003">Clear Skies Act of 2003</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EXsummary_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-EXsummary-156">[156]</a></sup> aimed at amending the <a href="/wiki/Clean_Air_Act_(United_States)" title="Clean Air Act (United States)">Clean Air Act</a> to reduce air pollution through the use of <a href="/wiki/Emissions_trading" title="Emissions trading">emissions trading</a> programs. Many experts argued that this legislation would have weakened the original legislation by allowing higher emission rates of pollutants than were previously legal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup> The initiative was introduced to Congress, but failed to make it out of committee.</p>
<p>Later in 2006, Bush declared the <a href="/wiki/Northwestern_Hawaiian_Islands" title="Northwestern Hawaiian Islands">Northwestern Hawaiian Islands</a> a national monument, creating the largest <a href="/wiki/Marine_reserve" title="Marine reserve">marine reserve</a> to date. The <a href="/wiki/Papah%C4%81naumoku%C4%81kea_Marine_National_Monument" title="Papahānaumokuākea Marine National Monument">Papahānaumokuākea Marine National Monument</a> comprises 84 million acres (340,000 km<sup>2</sup>) and is home to 7,000 species of fish, birds, and other marine animals, many of which are specific to only those islands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup> The move was hailed by conservationists for "its foresight and leadership in protecting this incredible area".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup></p>
<p>Bush has said that he believes that <a href="/wiki/Global_warming" title="Global warming">global warming</a> is real<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup> and has noted that it is a serious problem, but he asserted there is a "debate over whether it's man-made or naturally caused".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[161]</a></sup> The Bush Administration's stance on global warming remained controversial in the scientific and environmental communities. Critics have alleged that the administration<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[162]</a></sup> misinformed the public and did not do enough to reduce <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gas#Greenhouse_gas_emissions" title="Greenhouse gas">carbon emissions</a> and deter global warming.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[163]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy_policies">Energy policies</span></h4>
<p>In his <a href="/wiki/2006_State_of_the_Union_Address" title="2006 State of the Union Address">2006 State of the Union Address</a>, Bush declared, "America is addicted to oil" and announced his Advanced Energy Initiative to increase <a href="/wiki/Energy_development" title="Energy development">energy development</a> research.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[164]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:20080618_Bush_Kempthorne_oil_exploration_speech.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="342" data-file-width="514" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/20080618_Bush_Kempthorne_oil_exploration_speech.jpg/220px-20080618_Bush_Kempthorne_oil_exploration_speech.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/20080618_Bush_Kempthorne_oil_exploration_speech.jpg/330px-20080618_Bush_Kempthorne_oil_exploration_speech.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/20080618_Bush_Kempthorne_oil_exploration_speech.jpg/440px-20080618_Bush_Kempthorne_oil_exploration_speech.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:20080618_Bush_Kempthorne_oil_exploration_speech.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
President Bush delivering a statement on energy, urging Congress to end <a href="/wiki/Offshore_oil_and_gas_in_the_United_States" title="Offshore oil and gas in the United States">offshore oil drill</a> ban, June 18, 2008</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>In his <a href="/wiki/2007_State_of_the_Union_Address" title="2007 State of the Union Address">2007 State of the Union Address</a>, Bush renewed his pledge to work toward diminished reliance on foreign oil by reducing <a href="/wiki/Fossil_fuel" title="Fossil fuel">fossil fuel</a> consumption and increasing <a href="/wiki/Alternative_fuel" title="Alternative fuel">alternative fuel</a> production.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[165]</a></sup> Amid high gasoline prices in 2008, Bush lifted a ban on <a href="/wiki/Offshore_drilling" title="Offshore drilling">offshore drilling</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-drilling-cnn_166-0"><a href="#cite_note-drilling-cnn-166">[166]</a></sup> However, the move was largely symbolic because there was still a federal law banning offshore drilling. Bush said, "This means that the only thing standing between the American people and these vast oil reserves is action from the U.S. Congress."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-drilling-cnn_166-1"><a href="#cite_note-drilling-cnn-166">[166]</a></sup> Bush had said in June 2008, "In the long run, the solution is to reduce demand for oil by promoting alternative energy technologies. My administration has worked with Congress to invest in gas-saving technologies like advanced batteries and hydrogen <a href="/wiki/Fuel_cell" title="Fuel cell">fuel cells</a>... In the short run, the American economy will continue to rely largely on oil. And that means we need to increase supply, especially here at home. So my administration has repeatedly called on Congress to expand domestic oil production."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[167]</a></sup></p>
<p>In his <a href="/wiki/2008_State_of_the_Union_Address" title="2008 State of the Union Address">2008 State of the Union Address</a>, Bush announced that the U.S. would commit $2 billion over the next three years to a new international fund to promote clean energy technologies and fight climate change, saying, "Along with contributions from other countries, this fund will increase and accelerate the deployment of all forms of cleaner, more efficient technologies in developing nations like India and China, and help leverage substantial private-sector capital by making clean energy projects more financially attractive." He also announced plans to reaffirm the United States' commitment to work with major economies, and, through the UN, to complete an international agreement that will slow, stop, and eventually reverse the growth of greenhouse gases; he stated, "This agreement will be effective only if it includes commitments by every major economy and gives none a free ride."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[168]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Stem_cell_research_and_first_veto">Stem cell research and first veto</span></h4>
<p>Federal funding for medical research involving the creation or destruction of human embryos through the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Department_of_Health_and_Human_Services" title="Department of Health and Human Services">Department of Health and Human Services</a> and the <a href="/wiki/National_Institutes_of_Health" title="National Institutes of Health">National Institutes of Health</a> has been forbidden by law since the passage in 1995 of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dickey-Wicker_Amendment" title="Dickey-Wicker Amendment">Dickey-Wicker Amendment</a> by Congress and the signature of President <a href="/wiki/Bill_Clinton" title="Bill Clinton">Bill Clinton</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[169]</a></sup> Bush has said that he supports adult <a href="/wiki/Stem_cell" title="Stem cell">stem cell</a> research and has supported federal legislation that finances adult stem cell research. However, Bush did not support <a href="/wiki/Embryonic_stem_cell" title="Embryonic stem cell">embryonic stem cell</a> research.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[170]</a></sup> On August 9, 2001, Bush signed an executive order lifting the ban on federal funding for the 71 existing "lines" of stem cells,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[171]</a></sup> but the ability of these existing lines to provide an adequate medium for testing has been questioned. Testing can be done on only 12 of the original lines, and all approved lines have been cultured in contact with mouse cells, which creates safety issues that complicate development and approval of therapies from these lines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup> On July 19, 2006, Bush used his veto power for the first time in his presidency to veto the <a href="/wiki/Stem_Cell_Research_Enhancement_Act" title="Stem Cell Research Enhancement Act">Stem Cell Research Enhancement Act</a>. The bill would have repealed the Dickey-Wicker Amendment, thereby permitting federal money to be used for research where stem cells are derived from the destruction of an embryo.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[173]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Genetic_Nondiscrimination">Genetic Nondiscrimination</span></h4>
<p>On May 21, 2008 President George W. Bush signed into law the <a href="/wiki/Genetic_Information_Nondiscrimination_Act" title="Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act">Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act</a> (GINA).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[174]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[175]</a></sup> The bill aims to protect Americans against discrimination based on their genetic information when it comes to health insurance and employment. The issue had been debated for 13 years before becoming law. It is designed to protect citizens while not hindering genetic research.</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Immigration">Immigration</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bush_delivers_statement_at_Mexican_border.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="359" data-file-width="514" height="154" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Bush_delivers_statement_at_Mexican_border.jpg/220px-Bush_delivers_statement_at_Mexican_border.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Bush_delivers_statement_at_Mexican_border.jpg/330px-Bush_delivers_statement_at_Mexican_border.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Bush_delivers_statement_at_Mexican_border.jpg/440px-Bush_delivers_statement_at_Mexican_border.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bush_delivers_statement_at_Mexican_border.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
President Bush discussing border security with Homeland Security Director <a href="/wiki/Michael_Chertoff" title="Michael Chertoff">Michael Chertoff</a> near <a href="/wiki/El_Paso,_Texas" title="El Paso, Texas">El Paso</a>, November 2005</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Nearly 8 million immigrants came to the United States from 2000 to 2005, more than in any other five-year period in the nation's history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[176]</a></sup> Almost half entered illegally.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[177]</a></sup> In 2006, Bush urged Congress to allow more than 12 million <a href="/wiki/Illegal_immigration" title="Illegal immigration">illegal immigrants</a> to work in the United States with the creation of a "temporary guest-worker program". Bush also urged Congress to provide additional funds for border security and committed to deploying 6,000 <a href="/wiki/National_Guard_of_the_United_States" title="National Guard of the United States">National Guard</a> troops to the <a href="/wiki/Mexico%E2%80%93United_States_border" title="Mexico–United States border">Mexico–United States border</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[178]</a></sup> From May to June 2007, Bush strongly supported the <a href="/wiki/Comprehensive_Immigration_Reform_Act_of_2007" title="Comprehensive Immigration Reform Act of 2007">Comprehensive Immigration Reform Act of 2007</a>, which was written by a bipartisan group of Senators with the active participation of the Bush administration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup> The bill envisioned a legalization program for illegal immigrants, with an eventual path to citizenship; establishing a guest worker program; a series of border and work site enforcement measures; a reform of the <a href="/wiki/Permanent_residence_(United_States)" title="Permanent residence (United States)">green card</a> application process and the introduction of a point-based "merit" system for green cards; elimination of "<a href="/wiki/Chain_migration" title="Chain migration">chain migration</a>" and of the <a href="/wiki/Diversity_Immigrant_Visa" title="Diversity Immigrant Visa">Diversity Immigrant Visa</a>; and other measures. Bush argued that the lack of legal status denies the protections of U.S. laws to millions of people who face dangers of poverty and exploitation, and penalizes employers despite a demand for immigrant labor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[180]</a></sup> Bush contended that the proposed bill did not amount to amnesty.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[181]</a></sup></p>
<p>A heated public debate followed, which resulted in a substantial rift within the Republican Party, most conservatives opposed it because of its legalization or amnesty provisions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup> The bill was eventually defeated in the Senate on June 28, 2007, when a <a href="/wiki/Cloture" title="Cloture">cloture</a> motion failed on a 46–53 vote.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[183]</a></sup> Bush expressed disappointment upon the defeat of one of his signature domestic initiatives.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[184]</a></sup> The Bush administration later proposed a series of immigration enforcement measures that do not require a change in law.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[185]</a></sup></p>
<p>On September 19, 2010, former Israeli Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Ehud_Olmert" title="Ehud Olmert">Ehud Olmert</a> said that Bush offered to accept 100,000 Palestinian refugees as American citizens if a permanent settlement had been reached between Israel and the Palestinian Authority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[186]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Hurricane_Katrina">Hurricane Katrina</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Political_effects_of_Hurricane_Katrina" title="Political effects of Hurricane Katrina">Political effects of Hurricane Katrina</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hurricane_Katrina_President_Bush_with_New_Orleans_Mayor.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="356" data-file-width="514" height="152" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Hurricane_Katrina_President_Bush_with_New_Orleans_Mayor.jpg/220px-Hurricane_Katrina_President_Bush_with_New_Orleans_Mayor.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Hurricane_Katrina_President_Bush_with_New_Orleans_Mayor.jpg/330px-Hurricane_Katrina_President_Bush_with_New_Orleans_Mayor.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Hurricane_Katrina_President_Bush_with_New_Orleans_Mayor.jpg/440px-Hurricane_Katrina_President_Bush_with_New_Orleans_Mayor.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hurricane_Katrina_President_Bush_with_New_Orleans_Mayor.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
President Bush shaking hands with New Orleans Mayor <a href="/wiki/Ray_Nagin" title="Ray Nagin">Ray Nagin</a> after viewing the devastation of Hurricane Katrina, September 2, 2005</div>
</div>
</div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Katrina" title="Hurricane Katrina">Hurricane Katrina</a>, one of the most damaging natural disasters in U.S. history, struck early in Bush's second term. Katrina formed in late August during the 2005 <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic</a> hurricane season and devastated much of the north-central <a href="/wiki/Gulf_Coast_of_the_United_States" title="Gulf Coast of the United States">Gulf Coast of the United States</a>, particularly New Orleans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[187]</a></sup></p>
<p>Bush declared a state of emergency in <a href="/wiki/Louisiana" title="Louisiana">Louisiana</a> on August 27,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[188]</a></sup> and in <a href="/wiki/Mississippi" title="Mississippi">Mississippi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alabama" title="Alabama">Alabama</a> the following day;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[189]</a></sup> he authorized the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Homeland_Security" title="United States Department of Homeland Security">Department of Homeland Security</a> (DHS) and <a href="/wiki/Federal_Emergency_Management_Agency" title="Federal Emergency Management Agency">Federal Emergency Management Agency</a> (FEMA) to manage the disaster, but his announcement failed to spur these agencies to action.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dyson_190-0"><a href="#cite_note-dyson-190">[190]</a></sup> The eye of the hurricane made landfall on August 29, and New Orleans began to flood due to <a href="/wiki/Levee" title="Levee">levee</a> breaches; later that day, Bush declared that a major disaster existed in Louisiana,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[191]</a></sup> officially authorizing FEMA to start using federal funds to assist in the recovery effort.</p>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:President_Bush_Biloxi_after_Katrina.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="379" data-file-width="515" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/President_Bush_Biloxi_after_Katrina.jpg/220px-President_Bush_Biloxi_after_Katrina.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/President_Bush_Biloxi_after_Katrina.jpg/330px-President_Bush_Biloxi_after_Katrina.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/President_Bush_Biloxi_after_Katrina.jpg/440px-President_Bush_Biloxi_after_Katrina.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:President_Bush_Biloxi_after_Katrina.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
President Bush with hurricane victims in Biloxi, September 2, 2005</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>On August 30, DHS Secretary <a href="/wiki/Michael_Chertoff" title="Michael Chertoff">Michael Chertoff</a> declared it "an incident of national significance",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[192]</a></sup> triggering the first use of the newly created <a href="/wiki/National_Response_Plan" title="National Response Plan">National Response Plan</a>. Three days later, on September 2, National Guard troops first entered the city of New Orleans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tpm_193-0"><a href="#cite_note-tpm-193">[193]</a></sup> The same day, Bush toured parts of Louisiana, <a href="/wiki/Mississippi" title="Mississippi">Mississippi</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Alabama" title="Alabama">Alabama</a> and declared that the success of the recovery effort up to that point was "not enough".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USAToday-Katrina_194-0"><a href="#cite_note-USAToday-Katrina-194">[194]</a></sup></p>
<p>As the disaster in New Orleans intensified, critics charged that Bush was misrepresenting his administration's role in what they saw as a flawed response. Leaders attacked Bush for having appointed apparently incompetent leaders to positions of power at FEMA, notably <a href="/wiki/Michael_D._Brown" title="Michael D. Brown">Michael D. Brown</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[195]</a></sup> it was also argued that the federal response was limited as a result of the <a href="/wiki/Iraq_War" title="Iraq War">Iraq War</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ArmyTimesDeployment_196-0"><a href="#cite_note-ArmyTimesDeployment-196">[196]</a></sup> and Bush himself did not act upon warnings of floods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[197]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[198]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[199]</a></sup> Bush responded to mounting criticism by accepting full responsibility for the federal government's failures in its handling of the emergency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tpm_193-1"><a href="#cite_note-tpm-193">[193]</a></sup> It has been argued that with Katrina, Bush passed a political tipping point from which he would not recover.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[200]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Midterm_dismissal_of_U.S._attorneys">Midterm dismissal of U.S. attorneys</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Dismissal_of_U.S._attorneys_controversy" title="Dismissal of U.S. attorneys controversy">Dismissal of U.S. attorneys controversy</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:George_W_Bush_and_Alberto_Gonzales.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="348" data-file-width="514" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/George_W_Bush_and_Alberto_Gonzales.jpg/220px-George_W_Bush_and_Alberto_Gonzales.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/George_W_Bush_and_Alberto_Gonzales.jpg/330px-George_W_Bush_and_Alberto_Gonzales.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/George_W_Bush_and_Alberto_Gonzales.jpg/440px-George_W_Bush_and_Alberto_Gonzales.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:George_W_Bush_and_Alberto_Gonzales.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
President Bush announcing his nomination of Alberto Gonzales as the next U.S. Attorney General, November 10, 2004</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>During Bush's second term, a controversy arose over the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Justice" title="United States Department of Justice">Justice Department's</a> midterm dismissal of seven <a href="/wiki/United_States_Attorney" title="United States Attorney">United States Attorneys</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[201]</a></sup> The White House maintained that the U.S. attorneys were fired for poor performance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup> Attorney General <a href="/wiki/Alberto_Gonzales" title="Alberto Gonzales">Alberto Gonzales</a> later resigned over the issue, along with other senior members of the Justice Department.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[203]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[204]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/United_States_House_Committee_on_the_Judiciary" title="United States House Committee on the Judiciary">House Judiciary Committee</a> issued subpoenas for advisers <a href="/wiki/Harriet_Miers" title="Harriet Miers">Harriet Miers</a> and <a href="/wiki/Joshua_Bolten" title="Joshua Bolten">Josh Bolten</a> to testify regarding this matter, but Bush directed Miers and Bolten to not comply with those subpoenas, invoking his right of <a href="/wiki/Executive_privilege" title="Executive privilege">executive privilege</a>. Bush maintained that all of his advisers were protected under a broad executive privilege protection to receive candid advice. The Justice Department determined that the President's order was legal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[205]</a></sup></p>
<p>Although Congressional investigations focused on whether the Justice Department and the White House were using the U.S. Attorney positions for political advantage, no official findings have been released. On March 10, 2008, the Congress filed a federal lawsuit to enforce their issued subpoenas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[206]</a></sup> On July 31, 2008, a <a href="/wiki/United_States_district_court" title="United States district court">United States district court</a> judge ruled that Bush's top advisers were not immune from Congressional subpoenas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[207]</a></sup></p>
<p>In all, twelve Justice Department officials resigned rather than testify under oath before Congress. They included Attorney General <a href="/wiki/Alberto_Gonzales" title="Alberto Gonzales">Alberto Gonzales</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[208]</a></sup> and his chief of staff <a href="/wiki/Kyle_Sampson" title="Kyle Sampson">Kyle Sampson</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[209]</a></sup> Gonzales' liaison to the White House <a href="/wiki/Monica_Goodling" title="Monica Goodling">Monica Goodling</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[210]</a></sup> aide to the president <a href="/wiki/Karl_Rove" title="Karl Rove">Karl Rove</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[211]</a></sup> and his senior aide <a href="/wiki/Sara_Taylor" title="Sara Taylor">Sara Taylor</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-washingtonpost2007_212-0"><a href="#cite_note-washingtonpost2007-212">[212]</a></sup> In addition, legal counsel to the president <a href="/wiki/Harriet_Miers" title="Harriet Miers">Harriet Miers</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-twssffwe_213-0"><a href="#cite_note-twssffwe-213">[213]</a></sup> and deputy chief of staff to the president <a href="/wiki/Joshua_Bolten" title="Joshua Bolten">Joshua Bolten</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[214]</a></sup> were both found in <a href="/wiki/Contempt_of_Congress" title="Contempt of Congress">contempt of Congress</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-washingtonpost2007_212-1"><a href="#cite_note-washingtonpost2007-212">[212]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 2010, the Justice Department investigator concluded that though political considerations did play a part in as many as four of the attorney firings,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[215]</a></sup> the firings were "inappropriately political", but not criminal. According to the prosecutors, there was insufficient evidence to pursue prosecution for any criminal offense.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[216]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Purge_of_the_Central_Intelligence_Agency">Purge of the Central Intelligence Agency</span></h4>
<p>Following the resignation of CIA director <a href="/wiki/George_Tenet" title="George Tenet">George Tenet</a> in 2004, Bush nominated <a href="/wiki/Porter_Goss" title="Porter Goss">Porter Goss</a> to head the agency. The White House ordered Goss to purge agency officers who were disloyal to the administration. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-salon_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-salon-217">[217]</a></sup> After Goss' appointment, many of the CIA's senior agents were fired or quit. The CIA has been accused of deliberately leaking classified information to undermine the 2004 election. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wapo_218-0"><a href="#cite_note-wapo-218">[218]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_policy">Foreign policy</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_policy_of_the_George_W._Bush_administration" title="Foreign policy of the George W. Bush administration">Foreign policy of the George W. Bush administration</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:George_W._Bush_welcomes_Silvio_Berlusconi.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="413" data-file-width="514" height="177" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/George_W._Bush_welcomes_Silvio_Berlusconi.jpg/220px-George_W._Bush_welcomes_Silvio_Berlusconi.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/George_W._Bush_welcomes_Silvio_Berlusconi.jpg/330px-George_W._Bush_welcomes_Silvio_Berlusconi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/George_W._Bush_welcomes_Silvio_Berlusconi.jpg/440px-George_W._Bush_welcomes_Silvio_Berlusconi.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:George_W._Bush_welcomes_Silvio_Berlusconi.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
President Bush with <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Italy" title="Prime Minister of Italy">Italian Prime Minister</a> <a href="/wiki/Silvio_Berlusconi" title="Silvio Berlusconi">Silvio Berlusconi</a> in 2005</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:George_W_Bush_Overseas_Visits.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="477" data-file-width="940" height="112" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/George_W_Bush_Overseas_Visits.svg/220px-George_W_Bush_Overseas_Visits.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/George_W_Bush_Overseas_Visits.svg/330px-George_W_Bush_Overseas_Visits.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/George_W_Bush_Overseas_Visits.svg/440px-George_W_Bush_Overseas_Visits.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:George_W_Bush_Overseas_Visits.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Countries visited by President George W. Bush during his time in office</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>In July 2001, Bush visited <a href="/wiki/Pope_John_Paul_II" title="Pope John Paul II">Pope John Paul II</a> at Castel Gandolfo.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[219]</a></sup> During his Presidential campaign, Bush's <a href="/wiki/Foreign_policy_of_the_United_States" title="Foreign policy of the United States">foreign policy</a> platform included support for stronger economic and political relationship with <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>, especially <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">Mexico</a>, and a reduction of involvement in "<a href="/wiki/Nation-building" title="Nation-building">nation-building</a>" and other small-scale military engagements. The administration pursued a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_missile_defense" title="National missile defense">national missile defense</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[220]</a></sup> Bush was an advocate of China's entry into the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[221]</a></sup></p>
<p>In his 2002 State of the Union Address, Bush referred to an <a href="/wiki/Axis_of_evil" title="Axis of evil">axis of evil</a> including <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a> and <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">North Korea</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-suterror_222-0"><a href="#cite_note-suterror-222">[222]</a></sup> After the September 11 attacks on New York, Bush launched the War on Terror, in which the United States military and a small international coalition <a href="/wiki/Invasions_of_Afghanistan#U.S._.E2.80.93led_invasion" title="Invasions of Afghanistan">invaded Afghanistan</a>. In 2003, Bush then launched the <a href="/wiki/Iraq_War" title="Iraq War">invasion of Iraq</a>, searching for Weapons of Mass Destruction, which he described as being part of the War on Terrorism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[223]</a></sup> Those invasions led to the toppling of the <a href="/wiki/Taliban" title="Taliban">Taliban</a> regime in Afghanistan and the removal of <a href="/wiki/Saddam_Hussein" title="Saddam Hussein">Saddam Hussein</a> from power in Iraq.</p>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bush_meets_Pranab_Mukherjee.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="327" data-file-width="515" height="140" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Bush_meets_Pranab_Mukherjee.jpg/220px-Bush_meets_Pranab_Mukherjee.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Bush_meets_Pranab_Mukherjee.jpg/330px-Bush_meets_Pranab_Mukherjee.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Bush_meets_Pranab_Mukherjee.jpg/440px-Bush_meets_Pranab_Mukherjee.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bush_meets_Pranab_Mukherjee.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Foreign Minister of India <a href="/wiki/Pranab_Mukherjee" title="Pranab Mukherjee">Pranab Mukherjee</a> with President Bush, March 2008</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Bush began his second term with an emphasis on improving strained relations with European nations. He appointed long-time adviser <a href="/wiki/Karen_Hughes" title="Karen Hughes">Karen Hughes</a> to oversee a global public relations campaign. Bush lauded the pro-democracy struggles in Georgia and Ukraine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[224]</a></sup></p>
<p>In March 2006, a visit to India led to renewed ties between the two countries, reversing decades of U.S. policy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[225]</a></sup> The visit focused particularly on areas of <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power" title="Nuclear power">nuclear energy</a> and counter-terrorism cooperation, discussions that would lead eventually to the <a href="/wiki/India%E2%80%93United_States_Civil_Nuclear_Agreement" title="India–United States Civil Nuclear Agreement">India–United States Civil Nuclear Agreement</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[226]</a></sup></p>
<p>This is in stark contrast to the stance taken by his predecessor, Clinton, whose approach and response to India after the 1998 nuclear tests was that of sanctions and hectoring. The relationship between India and the United States was one that dramatically improved during Bush's tenure.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[227]</a></sup></p>
<p>Midway through Bush's second term, it was questioned whether Bush was retreating from his freedom and democracy agenda, highlighted in policy changes toward some oil-rich former Soviet republics in central Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[228]</a></sup></p>
<p>In an address before both Houses of Congress on September 20, 2001, Bush thanked the nations of the world for their support following the September 11 attacks. He specifically thanked <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Prime Minister of the United Kingdom">UK Prime Minister</a> <a href="/wiki/Tony_Blair" title="Tony Blair">Tony Blair</a> for traveling to Washington to show "unity of purpose with America", and said "America has no truer friend than Great Britain."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[229]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="September_11_attacks">September 11 attacks</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">September 11 attacks</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:FEMA_-_3905_-_Photograph_by_SFC_Thomas_R._Roberts_taken_on_09-14-2001_in_New_York.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1312" data-file-width="2000" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/FEMA_-_3905_-_Photograph_by_SFC_Thomas_R._Roberts_taken_on_09-14-2001_in_New_York.jpg/220px-FEMA_-_3905_-_Photograph_by_SFC_Thomas_R._Roberts_taken_on_09-14-2001_in_New_York.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/FEMA_-_3905_-_Photograph_by_SFC_Thomas_R._Roberts_taken_on_09-14-2001_in_New_York.jpg/330px-FEMA_-_3905_-_Photograph_by_SFC_Thomas_R._Roberts_taken_on_09-14-2001_in_New_York.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/FEMA_-_3905_-_Photograph_by_SFC_Thomas_R._Roberts_taken_on_09-14-2001_in_New_York.jpg/440px-FEMA_-_3905_-_Photograph_by_SFC_Thomas_R._Roberts_taken_on_09-14-2001_in_New_York.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:FEMA_-_3905_-_Photograph_by_SFC_Thomas_R._Roberts_taken_on_09-14-2001_in_New_York.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
President Bush, standing with firefighter <a href="/wiki/Bob_Beckwith" title="Bob Beckwith">Bob Beckwith</a>, addressing rescue workers at <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_site" title="World Trade Center site">Ground Zero</a> in New York, September 14, 2001</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The September 11 terrorist attacks were a major turning point in Bush's presidency. That evening, he addressed the nation from the <a href="/wiki/Oval_Office" title="Oval Office">Oval Office</a>, promising a strong response to the attacks. He also emphasized the need for the nation to come together and comfort the families of the victims. On September 14, he visited <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_site" title="World Trade Center site">Ground Zero</a>, meeting with Mayor <a href="/wiki/Rudy_Giuliani" title="Rudy Giuliani">Rudy Giuliani</a>, firefighters, police officers, and volunteers. Bush addressed the gathering via a megaphone while standing on a heap of rubble, to much applause: "I can hear you. The rest of the world hears you. And the people who knocked these buildings down will hear all of us soon."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[230]</a></sup></p>
<table class="mbox-small" role="presentation" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000;">
<tr>
<td class="mbox-image">
<div class="center">
<div class="floatnone"><img alt="" data-file-height="48" data-file-width="48" height="50" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Audio-input-microphone.svg/50px-Audio-input-microphone.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Audio-input-microphone.svg/75px-Audio-input-microphone.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Audio-input-microphone.svg/100px-Audio-input-microphone.svg.png 2x" width="50"/></div>
</div>
</td>
<td class="mbox-text plainlist" style="line-height:1.1em">
<div class="haudio">
<div style="padding:4px 0"><a href="/wiki/File:Bush_Addresses_Congress_9-20-01.ogg" title="File:Bush Addresses Congress 9-20-01.ogg">President Bush Declares 'Freedom at War with Fear', September 20, 2001</a></div>
<div>
<div class="mediaContainer" style="width:220px"><audio class="kskin" controls="" data-durationhint="2057.346031746" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" data-mwtitle="Bush_Addresses_Congress_9-20-01.ogg" data-startoffset="0" id="mwe_player_0" preload="none" style="width:220px">
<source data-bandwidth="119373" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" data-title="Original Ogg file (119 kbps)" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1a/Bush_Addresses_Congress_9-20-01.ogg" type='audio/ogg; codecs="vorbis"'/></audio></div>
</div>
<div class="description" style="padding:2px 0 0 0"></div>
</div>
<hr/></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="mbox-text" colspan="2" style="line-height:1.1em"><span><i>Problems playing this file? See <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Media_help" title="Wikipedia:Media help">media help</a>.</i></span></td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>In a September 20 speech, Bush condemned <a href="/wiki/Osama_bin_Laden" title="Osama bin Laden">Osama bin Laden</a> and his organization <a href="/wiki/Al-Qaeda" title="Al-Qaeda">Al-Qaeda</a>, and issued an ultimatum to the Taliban regime in Afghanistan, where bin Laden was operating, to "hand over the terrorists, or ... share in their fate".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[231]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="War_on_Terrorism">War on Terrorism</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/War_on_Terror" title="War on Terror">War on Terror</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Blair_MOF.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="356" data-file-width="514" height="152" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Blair_MOF.jpg/220px-Blair_MOF.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Blair_MOF.jpg/330px-Blair_MOF.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Blair_MOF.jpg/440px-Blair_MOF.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Blair_MOF.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
President Bush presenting former British Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Tony_Blair" title="Tony Blair">Tony Blair</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Presidential_Medal_of_Freedom" title="Presidential Medal of Freedom">Presidential Medal of Freedom</a>, January 13, 2009</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>After September 11, Bush announced a global War on Terror. The Afghan Taliban regime was not forthcoming with Osama bin Laden, so Bush ordered the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Afghanistan_invasion" title="Afghanistan invasion">invasion of Afghanistan</a> to overthrow the Taliban regime.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[232]</a></sup> In his January 29, <a href="/wiki/2002_State_of_the_Union_Address" title="2002 State of the Union Address">2002 State of the Union Address</a>, he asserted that an "<a href="/wiki/Axis_of_evil" title="Axis of evil">axis of evil</a>" consisting of North Korea, Iran, and Iraq was "arming to threaten the peace of the world" and "pose[d] a grave and growing danger".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sotu2002_233-0"><a href="#cite_note-sotu2002-233">[233]</a></sup> The Bush Administration asserted both a right and the intention to wage <a href="/wiki/Preemptive_war" title="Preemptive war">preemptive war</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Preventive_war" title="Preventive war">preventive war</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234"><a href="#cite_note-234">[234]</a></sup> This became the basis for the <a href="/wiki/Bush_Doctrine" title="Bush Doctrine">Bush Doctrine</a> which weakened the unprecedented levels of international and domestic support for the United States which had followed the September 11 attacks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[235]</a></sup></p>
<p>Dissent and criticism of Bush's leadership in the War on Terror increased as the war in Iraq continued.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[236]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[237]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[238]</a></sup> In 2006, a <a href="/wiki/National_Intelligence_Estimate" title="National Intelligence Estimate">National Intelligence Estimate</a> concluded that the Iraq War had become the "<a href="/wiki/Cause_c%C3%A9l%C3%A8bre" title="Cause célèbre">cause célèbre</a> for <a href="/wiki/Jihad" title="Jihad">jihadists</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[239]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[240]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Afghanistan_invasion">Afghanistan invasion</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%9314)" title="War in Afghanistan (2001–14)">War in Afghanistan (2001–14)</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GW_Bush_and_Hamid_Karzai_in_Kabul_2006-03-01.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="321" data-file-width="391" height="181" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/GW_Bush_and_Hamid_Karzai_in_Kabul_2006-03-01.jpg/220px-GW_Bush_and_Hamid_Karzai_in_Kabul_2006-03-01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/GW_Bush_and_Hamid_Karzai_in_Kabul_2006-03-01.jpg/330px-GW_Bush_and_Hamid_Karzai_in_Kabul_2006-03-01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4c/GW_Bush_and_Hamid_Karzai_in_Kabul_2006-03-01.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GW_Bush_and_Hamid_Karzai_in_Kabul_2006-03-01.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
President Bush and President <a href="/wiki/Hamid_Karzai" title="Hamid Karzai">Hamid Karzai</a> of Afghanistan appearing at a joint news conference in Kabul, March 1, 2006</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>On October 7, 2001, U.S. and British forces initiated bombing campaigns that led to the arrival of <a href="/wiki/Northern_Alliance" title="Northern Alliance">Northern Alliance</a> troops in <a href="/wiki/Kabul" title="Kabul">Kabul</a> on November 13. The main goals of the war were to defeat the <a href="/wiki/Taliban" title="Taliban">Taliban</a>, drive <a href="/wiki/Al-Qaeda" title="Al-Qaeda">al-Qaeda</a> out of Afghanistan, and capture key al-Qaeda leaders. In December 2001, the Pentagon reported that the Taliban had been defeated,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-taliband_241-0"><a href="#cite_note-taliband-241">[241]</a></sup> but cautioned that the war would go on to continue weakening Taliban and al-Qaeda leaders.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-taliband_241-1"><a href="#cite_note-taliband-241">[241]</a></sup> Later that month the UN had installed the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Afghan_Transitional_Administration" title="Afghan Transitional Administration">Afghan Transitional Administration</a> chaired by <a href="/wiki/Hamid_Karzai" title="Hamid Karzai">Hamid Karzai</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[242]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[243]</a></sup> In 2002, based on <a href="/wiki/UNICEF" title="UNICEF">UNICEF</a> figures, <a href="/wiki/Nicholas_Kristof" title="Nicholas Kristof">Nicholas Kristof</a> reported that "our invasion of Afghanistan may end up saving one million lives over the next decade" as the result of improved healthcare and greater access to humanitarian aid.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[244]</a></sup></p>
<p>Efforts to kill or capture al-Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden failed as he escaped a battle in December 2001 in the mountainous region of <a href="/wiki/Tora_Bora" title="Tora Bora">Tora Bora</a>, which the Bush Administration later acknowledged to have resulted from a failure to commit enough U.S. ground troops.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[245]</a></sup> It was not until May 2011, two years after Bush left office, that bin Laden was killed by U.S. forces under the Obama administration. Bin Laden's successor, <a href="/wiki/Ayman_al-Zawahiri" title="Ayman al-Zawahiri">Ayman al-Zawahiri</a>, remains at large.</p>
<p>Despite the initial success in driving the Taliban from power in Kabul, by early 2003 the Taliban was regrouping, amassing new funds and recruits.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[246]</a></sup> The 2005 failure of <a href="/wiki/Operation_Red_Wings" title="Operation Red Wings">Operation Red Wings</a> showed that the Taliban had returned.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[247]</a></sup> In 2006, the <a href="/wiki/Taliban_insurgency" title="Taliban insurgency">Taliban insurgency</a> appeared larger, fiercer and better organized than expected, with large-scale allied offensives such as <a href="/wiki/Operation_Mountain_Thrust" title="Operation Mountain Thrust">Operation Mountain Thrust</a> attaining limited success.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[248]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[249]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250">[250]</a></sup> As a result, Bush commissioned 3,500 additional troops to the country in March 2007.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[251]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Iraq_invasion">Iraq invasion</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Iraq_War" title="Iraq War">Iraq War</a> and <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush_and_the_Iraq_War" title="George W. Bush and the Iraq War">George W. Bush and the Iraq War</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:George_W._Bush_walks_with_Ryan_Phillips_to_Navy_One.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="664" data-file-width="515" height="219" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/George_W._Bush_walks_with_Ryan_Phillips_to_Navy_One.jpg/170px-George_W._Bush_walks_with_Ryan_Phillips_to_Navy_One.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/George_W._Bush_walks_with_Ryan_Phillips_to_Navy_One.jpg/255px-George_W._Bush_walks_with_Ryan_Phillips_to_Navy_One.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/George_W._Bush_walks_with_Ryan_Phillips_to_Navy_One.jpg/340px-George_W._Bush_walks_with_Ryan_Phillips_to_Navy_One.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:George_W._Bush_walks_with_Ryan_Phillips_to_Navy_One.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
President Bush, with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Naval_Flight_Officer" title="Naval Flight Officer">Naval Flight Officer</a> Lieutenant Ryan Philips, after landing on the USS <i>Abraham Lincoln</i> prior to his <a href="/wiki/Mission_Accomplished_speech" title="Mission Accomplished speech">Mission Accomplished speech</a>, May 1, 2003</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Beginning with his January 29, 2002 <a href="/wiki/State_of_the_Union" title="State of the Union">State of the Union</a> address, Bush began publicly focusing attention on Iraq, which he labeled as part of an "<a href="/wiki/Axis_of_evil" title="Axis of evil">axis of evil</a>" allied with terrorists and posing "a grave and growing danger" to U.S. interests through possession of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Weapons of mass destruction">weapons of mass destruction</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sotu2002_233-1"><a href="#cite_note-sotu2002-233">[233]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[252]</a></sup></p>
<p>In the latter half of 2002, CIA <a href="/wiki/National_Intelligence_Estimate" title="National Intelligence Estimate">reports</a> contained assertions of <a href="/wiki/Saddam_Hussein" title="Saddam Hussein">Saddam Hussein</a>'s intent of reconstituting nuclear weapons programs, not properly accounting for Iraqi <a href="/wiki/Biological_warfare" title="Biological warfare">biological</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chemical_warfare" title="Chemical warfare">chemical weapons</a>, and that some Iraqi missiles had a range greater than allowed by the UN sanctions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253"><a href="#cite_note-253">[253]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[254]</a></sup> Contentions that the Bush Administration manipulated or exaggerated the threat and evidence of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction capabilities would eventually become a major point of criticism for the president.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[255]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[256]</a></sup></p>
<p>In late 2002 and early 2003, Bush urged the United Nations to enforce Iraqi <a href="/wiki/Disarmament" title="Disarmament">disarmament</a> mandates, precipitating a <a href="/wiki/Iraq_disarmament_crisis" title="Iraq disarmament crisis">diplomatic crisis</a>. In November 2002, Hans Blix and <a href="/wiki/Mohamed_ElBaradei" title="Mohamed ElBaradei">Mohamed ElBaradei</a> led UN weapons inspectors in Iraq, but were advised by the U.S. to depart the country four days prior to the U.S. invasion, despite their requests for more time to complete their tasks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[257]</a></sup> The U.S. initially sought a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UN_Security_Council" title="UN Security Council">UN Security Council</a> resolution authorizing the use of military force but dropped the bid for UN approval due to vigorous opposition from several countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[258]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:US_Navy_031127-F-5435R-006_President_George_W._Bush_pays_a_surprise_visit_to_Baghdad_International_Airport_(BIAP).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1956" data-file-width="2850" height="151" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/US_Navy_031127-F-5435R-006_President_George_W._Bush_pays_a_surprise_visit_to_Baghdad_International_Airport_%28BIAP%29.jpg/220px-US_Navy_031127-F-5435R-006_President_George_W._Bush_pays_a_surprise_visit_to_Baghdad_International_Airport_%28BIAP%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/US_Navy_031127-F-5435R-006_President_George_W._Bush_pays_a_surprise_visit_to_Baghdad_International_Airport_%28BIAP%29.jpg/330px-US_Navy_031127-F-5435R-006_President_George_W._Bush_pays_a_surprise_visit_to_Baghdad_International_Airport_%28BIAP%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/US_Navy_031127-F-5435R-006_President_George_W._Bush_pays_a_surprise_visit_to_Baghdad_International_Airport_%28BIAP%29.jpg/440px-US_Navy_031127-F-5435R-006_President_George_W._Bush_pays_a_surprise_visit_to_Baghdad_International_Airport_%28BIAP%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:US_Navy_031127-F-5435R-006_President_George_W._Bush_pays_a_surprise_visit_to_Baghdad_International_Airport_(BIAP).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
President Bush paying a surprise visit to <a href="/wiki/Baghdad_International_Airport" title="Baghdad International Airport">Baghdad International Airport</a>, November 27, 2003</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>More than 20 nations (most notably the United Kingdom), designated the "<a href="/wiki/Multi-National_Force_%E2%80%93_Iraq" title="Multi-National Force – Iraq">coalition of the willing</a>" joined the United States<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[259]</a></sup> in invading Iraq. They launched the invasion on March 20, 2003. The Iraqi military was quickly defeated. The capital, <a href="/wiki/Baghdad" title="Baghdad">Baghdad</a>, fell on April 9, 2003. On May 1, Bush declared the end of major combat operations in Iraq. The initial success of U.S. operations increased his popularity, but the U.S. and allied forces faced a growing insurgency led by sectarian groups; Bush's "<a href="/wiki/Mission_Accomplished_speech" title="Mission Accomplished speech">Mission Accomplished</a>" speech was later criticized as premature.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[260]</a></sup> From 2004 until 2007, the situation in Iraq deteriorated further, with some observers arguing that there was a full-scale <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sectarian_violence_in_Iraq_(2006%E2%80%9307)" title="Sectarian violence in Iraq (2006–07)">civil war in Iraq</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[261]</a></sup> Bush's policies met with criticism, including demands domestically to set a timetable to withdraw troops from Iraq. The 2006 report of the bipartisan <a href="/wiki/Iraq_Study_Group" title="Iraq Study Group">Iraq Study Group</a>, led by <a href="/wiki/James_Baker" title="James Baker">James Baker</a>, concluded that the situation in Iraq was "grave and deteriorating". While Bush admitted that there were strategic mistakes made in regards to the stability of Iraq,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[262]</a></sup> he maintained he would not change the overall Iraq strategy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[263]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[264]</a></sup> According to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iraq_Body_Count" title="Iraq Body Count">Iraq Body Count</a>, some 251,000 Iraqis have been killed in the civil war following the U.S.-led invasion, including at least 163,841 civilians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[265]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bush_al-Maliki_handshake.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="368" data-file-width="514" height="158" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Bush_al-Maliki_handshake.jpg/220px-Bush_al-Maliki_handshake.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Bush_al-Maliki_handshake.jpg/330px-Bush_al-Maliki_handshake.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Bush_al-Maliki_handshake.jpg/440px-Bush_al-Maliki_handshake.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bush_al-Maliki_handshake.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
President Bush with Iraqi Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Nouri_al-Maliki" title="Nouri al-Maliki">Nouri al-Maliki</a>, July 25, 2006</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>In January 2005, free, democratic elections were held in Iraq for the first time in 50 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iraq_votes_266-0"><a href="#cite_note-iraq_votes-266">[266]</a></sup> According to Iraqi National Security Advisor <a href="/wiki/Mowaffak_al-Rubaie" title="Mowaffak al-Rubaie">Mowaffak al-Rubaie</a>, "This is the greatest day in the history of this country."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iraq_votes_266-1"><a href="#cite_note-iraq_votes-266">[266]</a></sup> Bush praised the event as well, saying that the Iraqis "have taken rightful control of their country's destiny".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iraq_votes_266-2"><a href="#cite_note-iraq_votes-266">[266]</a></sup> This led to the election of <a href="/wiki/Jalal_Talabani" title="Jalal Talabani">Jalal Talabani</a> as President and <a href="/wiki/Nouri_al-Maliki" title="Nouri al-Maliki">Nouri al-Maliki</a> as Prime Minister of Iraq. A referendum to approve a constitution in Iraq was held in October 2005, supported by most <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shiite" title="Shiite">Shiites</a> and many <a href="/wiki/Kurds" title="Kurds">Kurds</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[267]</a></sup></p>
<p>On January 10, 2007, Bush announced a <a href="/wiki/Iraq_War_troop_surge_of_2007" title="Iraq War troop surge of 2007">surge of 21,500 more troops for Iraq</a>, as well as a job program for Iraqis, more reconstruction proposals, and $1.2 billion for these programs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[268]</a></sup> On May 1, 2007, Bush used his second-ever veto to reject a bill setting a deadline for the withdrawal of U.S. troops,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[269]</a></sup> saying the debate over the conflict was "understandable" but insisting that a continued U.S. presence there was crucial.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[270]</a></sup></p>
<p>In March 2008, Bush praised the Iraqi government's "bold decision" to launch the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Basra_(2008)" title="Battle of Basra (2008)">Battle of Basra</a> against the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mahdi_Army" title="Mahdi Army">Mahdi Army</a>, calling it "a defining moment in the history of a free Iraq".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[271]</a></sup> He said he would carefully weigh recommendations from his commanding General <a href="/wiki/David_Petraeus" title="David Petraeus">David Petraeus</a> and Ambassador <a href="/wiki/Ryan_Crocker" title="Ryan Crocker">Ryan Crocker</a> about how to proceed after the end of the military buildup in the summer of 2008. He also praised the Iraqis' legislative achievements, including a pension law, a revised de-Baathification law, a new budget, an amnesty law, and a provincial powers measure that, he said, set the stage for the <a href="/wiki/Iraqi_governorate_elections,_2009" title="Iraqi governorate elections, 2009">Iraqi elections</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[272]</a></sup> By July 2008, American troop deaths had reached their lowest number since the war began,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cuts-nyt_273-0"><a href="#cite_note-cuts-nyt-273">[273]</a></sup> and due to increased stability in Iraq, Bush announced the withdrawal of additional American forces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cuts-nyt_273-1"><a href="#cite_note-cuts-nyt-273">[273]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Surveillance">Surveillance</span></h4>
<p>Following the events of September 11, Bush issued an executive order authorizing the <a href="/wiki/President%27s_Surveillance_Program" title="President's Surveillance Program">President's Surveillance Program</a> which included allowing the <a href="/wiki/National_Security_Agency" title="National Security Agency">NSA</a> to monitor communications between suspected terrorists outside the U.S and parties within the U.S. without obtaining a warrant as required by the <a href="/wiki/Foreign_Intelligence_Surveillance_Act" title="Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act">Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[274]</a></sup> As of 2009, the other provisions of the program remained highly classified.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IG_275-0"><a href="#cite_note-IG-275">[275]</a></sup> Once the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Justice" title="United States Department of Justice">Department of Justice</a> <a href="/wiki/Office_of_Legal_Counsel" title="Office of Legal Counsel">Office of Legal Counsel</a> questioned its original legal opinion that FISA did not apply in a time of war, the program was subsequently re-authorized by the President on the basis that the warrant requirements of FISA were implicitly superseded by the subsequent passage of the <a href="/wiki/Authorization_for_Use_of_Military_Force_Against_Terrorists" title="Authorization for Use of Military Force Against Terrorists">Authorization for Use of Military Force Against Terrorists</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[276]</a></sup> The program proved to be <a href="/wiki/NSA_warrantless_surveillance_(2001%E2%80%9307)" title="NSA warrantless surveillance (2001–07)">controversial</a>, as critics of the administration, as well as organizations such as the <a href="/wiki/American_Bar_Association" title="American Bar Association">American Bar Association</a>, argued that it was illegal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[277]</a></sup> In August 2006, a U.S. district court judge ruled that the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NSA_electronic_surveillance_program" title="NSA electronic surveillance program">NSA electronic surveillance program</a> was unconstitutional,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[278]</a></sup> but on July 6, 2007, that ruling was <a href="/wiki/Vacated_judgment" title="Vacated judgment">vacated</a> by the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Court_of_Appeals_for_the_Sixth_Circuit" title="United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit">United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit</a> on the grounds that the plaintiffs lacked <a href="/wiki/Standing_(law)" title="Standing (law)">standing</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[279]</a></sup> On January 17, 2007, Attorney General Alberto Gonzales informed U.S. Senate leaders that the program would not be reauthorized by the President, but would be subjected to judicial oversight.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280">[280]</a></sup> Later in 2007, the NSA launched a replacement for the program, referred to as <a href="/wiki/PRISM_(surveillance_program)" title="PRISM (surveillance program)">PRISM</a>, that was subject to the oversight of the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Foreign_Intelligence_Surveillance_Court" title="United States Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court">United States Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WaPo1_281-0"><a href="#cite_note-WaPo1-281">[281]</a></sup> This program was not publicly revealed until reports by <i><a href="/wiki/The_Washington_Post" title="The Washington Post">The Washington Post</a></i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WaPo1_281-1"><a href="#cite_note-WaPo1-281">[281]</a></sup> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a></i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Greenwald1_282-0"><a href="#cite_note-Greenwald1-282">[282]</a></sup> emerged in June 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WaPo1_281-2"><a href="#cite_note-WaPo1-281">[281]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Interrogation_policies">Interrogation policies</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Senate_Intelligence_Committee_report_on_CIA_torture" title="Senate Intelligence Committee report on CIA torture">Senate Intelligence Committee report on CIA torture</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Victory_Day_Parade_2005-17.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="334" data-file-width="500" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Victory_Day_Parade_2005-17.jpg/220px-Victory_Day_Parade_2005-17.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Victory_Day_Parade_2005-17.jpg/330px-Victory_Day_Parade_2005-17.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Victory_Day_Parade_2005-17.jpg/440px-Victory_Day_Parade_2005-17.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Victory_Day_Parade_2005-17.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
President Bush at the celebration of the sixtieth anniversary of victory in World War II, <a href="/wiki/Red_Square" title="Red Square">Red Square</a>, Moscow</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Bush authorized the <a href="/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Central Intelligence Agency">CIA</a> to use <a href="/wiki/Waterboarding" title="Waterboarding">waterboarding</a> and several other "<a href="/wiki/Enhanced_interrogation_techniques" title="Enhanced interrogation techniques">enhanced interrogation techniques</a>" that several critics, including Barack Obama, would label as torture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[283]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[284]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[285]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[286]</a></sup> Between 2002 and 2003 the CIA considered certain enhanced interrogation techniques, such as waterboarding, to be legal based on a secret Justice Department legal opinion arguing that terror detainees were not protected by the <a href="/wiki/Geneva_Conventions" title="Geneva Conventions">Geneva Conventions</a>' ban on torture and Vice President Cheney said enhanced interrogation including waterboarding was not torture or illegal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cbs-waterboard_287-0"><a href="#cite_note-cbs-waterboard-287">[287]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[288]</a></sup> The CIA had exercised the technique on certain key terrorist suspects under authority given to it in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bybee_Memo" title="Bybee Memo">Bybee Memo</a> from the Attorney General, though that memo was later withdrawn.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-certain_olc_289-0"><a href="#cite_note-certain_olc-289">[289]</a></sup> While not permitted by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Army_Field_Manuals" title="U.S. Army Field Manuals">U.S. Army Field Manuals</a> which assert "that harsh interrogation tactics elicit unreliable information",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cbs-waterboard_287-1"><a href="#cite_note-cbs-waterboard-287">[287]</a></sup> the Bush administration believed these enhanced interrogations "provided critical information" to preserve American lives.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[290]</a></sup>
