Critics, such as former CIA officer Bob Baer, have stated that information was suspect, "you can get anyone to confess to anything if the torture's bad enough."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[291]</a></sup></p>
<p>On October 17, 2006, Bush signed into law the <a href="/wiki/Military_Commissions_Act_of_2006" title="Military Commissions Act of 2006">Military Commissions Act of 2006</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-detainee_292-0"><a href="#cite_note-detainee-292">[292]</a></sup> a law enacted in the wake of the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States" title="Supreme Court of the United States">Supreme Court's</a> decision in <i><a href="/wiki/Hamdan_v._Rumsfeld" title="Hamdan v. Rumsfeld">Hamdan v. Rumsfeld</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_United_States_Supreme_Court_cases,_volume_548" title="List of United States Supreme Court cases, volume 548">548</a> <a href="/wiki/United_States_Reports" title="United States Reports">U.S.</a> <a class="external text" href="https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/548/557/" rel="nofollow">557</a> (2006),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[293]</a></sup> which allows the U.S. government to prosecute <a href="/wiki/Unlawful_combatant" title="Unlawful combatant">unlawful enemy combatants</a> by military commission rather than a standard trial. The law also denies them access to <i><a href="/wiki/Habeas_corpus" title="Habeas corpus">habeas corpus</a></i> and bars the torture of detainees, but allows the president to determine what constitutes torture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-detainee_292-1"><a href="#cite_note-detainee-292">[292]</a></sup></p>
<p>On March 8, 2008, Bush vetoed H.R. 2082,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[294]</a></sup> a bill that would have expanded congressional oversight over the intelligence community and banned the use of waterboarding as well as other forms of interrogation not permitted under the <a href="/wiki/FM_34-52_Intelligence_Interrogation" title="FM 34-52 Intelligence Interrogation">United States Army Field Manual on Human Intelligence Collector Operations</a>, saying that "the bill Congress sent me would take away one of the most valuable tools in the War on Terror".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[295]</a></sup> In April 2009, the ACLU sued and won release of the secret memos that had authorized the Bush administration's interrogation tactics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ass.27tAtt.27yGen.27lBybeeMemo_296-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ass.27tAtt.27yGen.27lBybeeMemo-296">[296]</a></sup> One memo detailed specific interrogation tactics including a footnote that described waterboarding as torture as well as that the form of waterboarding used by the CIA was far more intense than authorized by the Justice Department.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[297]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="North_Korea_condemnation">North Korea condemnation</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/North_Korea%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="North Korea–United States relations">North Korea–United States relations</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hu_Jintao_Bush.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="365" data-file-width="515" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Hu_Jintao_Bush.jpg/220px-Hu_Jintao_Bush.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Hu_Jintao_Bush.jpg/330px-Hu_Jintao_Bush.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Hu_Jintao_Bush.jpg/440px-Hu_Jintao_Bush.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hu_Jintao_Bush.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
President Bush with <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>'s President and <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_China" title="Communist Party of China">Communist Party</a> <a href="/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Communist_Party_of_China" title="General Secretary of the Communist Party of China">leader</a> <a href="/wiki/Hu_Jintao" title="Hu Jintao">Hu Jintao</a>, 2006</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Bush publicly condemned <a href="/wiki/Kim_Jong-il" title="Kim Jong-il">Kim Jong-il</a> of North Korea, naming North Korea one of three states in an "<a href="/wiki/Axis_of_evil" title="Axis of evil">axis of evil</a>", and saying that "the United States of America will not permit the world's most dangerous regimes to threaten us with the world's most destructive weapons."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sotu2002_233-2"><a href="#cite_note-sotu2002-233">[233]</a></sup> Within months, "both countries had walked away from their respective commitments under the U.S.–DPRK <a href="/wiki/Agreed_Framework" title="Agreed Framework">Agreed Framework</a> of October 1994."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[298]</a></sup> North Korea's October 9, 2006, <a href="/wiki/2006_North_Korean_nuclear_test" title="2006 North Korean nuclear test">detonation</a> of a nuclear device further complicated Bush's foreign policy, which centered for both terms of his presidency on "[preventing] the terrorists and regimes who seek chemical, biological, or nuclear weapons from threatening the United States and the world".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sotu2002_233-3"><a href="#cite_note-sotu2002-233">[233]</a></sup> Bush condemned North Korea's position, reaffirmed his commitment to "a nuclear-free Korean Peninsula", and stated that "transfer of nuclear weapons or material by North Korea to states or non-state entities would be considered a grave threat to the United States", for which North Korea would be held accountable.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_299-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-299">[299]</a></sup> On May 7, 2007, North Korea agreed to shut down its nuclear reactors immediately pending the release of frozen funds held in a foreign bank account. This was a result of a series of three-way talks initiated by the United States and including China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[300]</a></sup> On September 2, 2007, North Korea agreed to disclose and dismantle all of its nuclear programs by the end of 2007.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[301]</a></sup> By May 2009, North Korea had restarted its nuclear program and threatened to attack South Korea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302"><a href="#cite_note-302">[302]</a></sup></p>
<p>On June 22, 2010, "While South Korea prospers, the people of North Korea have suffered profoundly," he said, adding that, "communism had resulted in dire poverty, mass starvation and brutal suppression. "In recent years," he went on to say, "the suffering has been compounded by the leader who wasted North Korea's precious few resources on personal luxuries and nuclear weapons programs."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303"><a href="#cite_note-303">[303]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Syria_sanctions">Syria sanctions</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vladimir_Putin_at_APEC_Summit_in_China_19-21_October_2001-13.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="334" data-file-width="500" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Vladimir_Putin_at_APEC_Summit_in_China_19-21_October_2001-13.jpg/220px-Vladimir_Putin_at_APEC_Summit_in_China_19-21_October_2001-13.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Vladimir_Putin_at_APEC_Summit_in_China_19-21_October_2001-13.jpg/330px-Vladimir_Putin_at_APEC_Summit_in_China_19-21_October_2001-13.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Vladimir_Putin_at_APEC_Summit_in_China_19-21_October_2001-13.jpg/440px-Vladimir_Putin_at_APEC_Summit_in_China_19-21_October_2001-13.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vladimir_Putin_at_APEC_Summit_in_China_19-21_October_2001-13.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
President Bush with Russian president <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a> in Shanghai, October 21, 2001</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Bush expanded economic sanctions on Syria.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[304]</a></sup> In early 2007, the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_the_Treasury" title="United States Department of the Treasury">Treasury Department</a>, acting on a June 2005 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Executive_order" title="Executive order">executive order</a>, froze American bank accounts of Syria's Higher Institute of Applied Science and Technology, Electronics Institute, and National Standards and Calibration Laboratory. Bush's order prohibits Americans from doing business with these institutions suspected of helping spread <a href="/wiki/Weapon_of_mass_destruction" title="Weapon of mass destruction">weapons of mass destruction</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[305]</a></sup> and being supportive of terrorism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[306]</a></sup> Under separate executive orders signed by Bush in 2004 and later 2007, the Treasury Department froze the assets of two Lebanese and two Syrians, accusing them of activities to "undermine the legitimate political process in Lebanon" in November 2007. Those designated included: Assaad Halim Hardan, a member of Lebanon's parliament and current leader of the Syrian Socialist National Party; Wi'am Wahhab, a former member of Lebanon's government (Minister of the Environment) under Prime Minister Omar Karami (2004–2005); Hafiz Makhluf, a colonel and senior official in the Syrian General Intelligence Directorate and a cousin of Syrian President <a href="/wiki/Bashar_al-Assad" title="Bashar al-Assad">Bashar al-Assad</a>; and Muhammad Nasif Khayrbik, identified as a close adviser to Assad.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[307]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Africa">Africa</span></h4>
<p>Bush initiated the <a href="/wiki/President%27s_Emergency_Plan_for_AIDS_Relief" title="President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief">President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief</a> Program (PEPFAR). The U.S. government has spent some $44 billion on the project since 2003 (a figure that includes $7 billion contributed to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria, a multilateral organization),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[308]</a></sup> saving an estimated 5 million lives.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Foreign_Policy_309-0"><a href="#cite_note-Foreign_Policy-309">[309]</a></sup> According to <i>The New York Times</i> correspondent <a href="/wiki/Peter_Baker_(author)" title="Peter Baker (author)">Peter Baker</a>, "Bush did more to stop AIDS and more to help Africa than any president before or since."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Foreign_Policy_309-1"><a href="#cite_note-Foreign_Policy-309">[309]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Assassination_attempt">Assassination attempt</span></h4>
<p>On May 10, 2005, <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Arutyunian" title="Vladimir Arutyunian">Vladimir Arutyunian</a>, a native <a href="/wiki/Georgians" title="Georgians">Georgian</a> who was born to a family of ethnic <a href="/wiki/Armenians" title="Armenians">Armenians</a>, threw a live hand grenade toward a podium where Bush was speaking at <a href="/wiki/Freedom_Square,_Tbilisi" title="Freedom Square, Tbilisi">Freedom Square</a> in Tbilisi, <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgia</a>. Georgian President <a href="/wiki/Mikheil_Saakashvili" title="Mikheil Saakashvili">Mikheil Saakashvili</a> was seated nearby. It landed in the crowd about 65 feet (20 m) from the podium after hitting a girl, but it did not detonate. Arutyunian was arrested in July 2005, confessed, was convicted and was given a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Life_sentence" title="Life sentence">life sentence</a> in January 2006.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[310]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_issues">Other issues</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Red_Sea_Summit_in_Aqaba.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="339" data-file-width="514" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Red_Sea_Summit_in_Aqaba.jpg/220px-Red_Sea_Summit_in_Aqaba.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Red_Sea_Summit_in_Aqaba.jpg/330px-Red_Sea_Summit_in_Aqaba.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Red_Sea_Summit_in_Aqaba.jpg/440px-Red_Sea_Summit_in_Aqaba.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Red_Sea_Summit_in_Aqaba.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
President Bush, <a href="/wiki/Mahmoud_Abbas" title="Mahmoud Abbas">Mahmoud Abbas</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ariel_Sharon" title="Ariel Sharon">Ariel Sharon</a> meet at the Red Sea Summit in <a href="/wiki/Aqaba" title="Aqaba">Aqaba</a>, Jordan, June 4, 2003</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Bush withdrew U.S. support for several international agreements, including the <a href="/wiki/Anti-Ballistic_Missile_Treaty" title="Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty">Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty</a> (ABM) with Russia. He also signed the <a href="/wiki/Strategic_Offensive_Reductions_Treaty" title="Strategic Offensive Reductions Treaty">Strategic Offensive Reductions Treaty</a> with Russia.</p>
<p>Bush emphasized a careful approach to the conflict between Israel and the Palestinians; he denounced <a href="/wiki/Palestine_Liberation_Organization" title="Palestine Liberation Organization">Palestine Liberation Organization</a> leader <a href="/wiki/Yasser_Arafat" title="Yasser Arafat">Yasser Arafat</a> for his support of violence, but sponsored dialogues between Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Ariel_Sharon" title="Ariel Sharon">Ariel Sharon</a> and Palestinian National Authority President <a href="/wiki/Mahmoud_Abbas" title="Mahmoud Abbas">Mahmoud Abbas</a>. Bush supported Sharon's unilateral disengagement plan, and lauded the democratic elections held in Palestine after Arafat's death.</p>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GeorgeBush-Juliia_Tymoshenko_(2008)-Ukraine.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="724" data-file-width="515" height="239" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/GeorgeBush-Juliia_Tymoshenko_%282008%29-Ukraine.JPG/170px-GeorgeBush-Juliia_Tymoshenko_%282008%29-Ukraine.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/GeorgeBush-Juliia_Tymoshenko_%282008%29-Ukraine.JPG/255px-GeorgeBush-Juliia_Tymoshenko_%282008%29-Ukraine.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/GeorgeBush-Juliia_Tymoshenko_%282008%29-Ukraine.JPG/340px-GeorgeBush-Juliia_Tymoshenko_%282008%29-Ukraine.JPG 2x" width="170"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GeorgeBush-Juliia_Tymoshenko_(2008)-Ukraine.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
President Bush and Ukrainian Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Yulia_Tymoshenko" title="Yulia Tymoshenko">Yulia Tymoshenko</a>, April 1, 2008</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Bush also expressed U.S. support for the defense of Taiwan following the stand-off in April 2001 with the People's Republic of China over the <a href="/wiki/Hainan_Island_incident" title="Hainan Island incident">Hainan Island incident</a>, when an <a href="/wiki/Lockheed_EP-3" title="Lockheed EP-3">EP-3E Aries II</a> surveillance aircraft collided with a <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army_Air_Force" title="People's Liberation Army Air Force">People's Liberation Army Air Force</a> jet, leading to the detention of U.S. personnel. From 2003 to 2004, Bush authorized U.S. military intervention in Haiti and Liberia to protect U.S. interests. Bush condemned the <a href="/wiki/War_in_Darfur" title="War in Darfur">militia attacks Darfur</a> and denounced the killings in Sudan as genocide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311"><a href="#cite_note-311">[311]</a></sup> Bush said that an international peacekeeping presence was critical in Darfur, but opposed referring the situation to the <a href="/wiki/International_Criminal_Court" title="International Criminal Court">International Criminal Court</a>.</p>
<p>In the State of the Union address in January 2003, Bush outlined a five-year strategy for global emergency AIDS relief, the <a href="/wiki/President%27s_Emergency_Plan_for_AIDS_Relief" title="President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief">President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief</a>. Bush announced $15 billion for this effort<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[312]</a></sup> which directly supported life-saving antiretroviral treatment for more than 3.2 million men, women and children worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[313]</a></sup></p>
<p>On June 10, 2007, Bush met with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Albanian_Prime_Minister" title="Albanian Prime Minister">Albanian Prime Minister</a> <a href="/wiki/Sali_Berisha" title="Sali Berisha">Sali Berisha</a> and became the first president to visit Albania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314"><a href="#cite_note-314">[314]</a></sup> Bush has voiced his support for the <a href="/wiki/2008_Kosovo_declaration_of_independence" title="2008 Kosovo declaration of independence">independence</a> of Kosovo.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[315]</a></sup> Bush opposed <a href="/wiki/South_Ossetia" title="South Ossetia">South Ossetia</a>'s independence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316"><a href="#cite_note-316">[316]</a></sup> On August 15, 2008, Bush said of Russia's invasion of the country of <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgia</a>: "Bullying and intimidation are not acceptable ways to conduct foreign policy in the 21st century."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317"><a href="#cite_note-317">[317]</a></sup></p>
<p>Bush opened the <a href="/wiki/2002_Winter_Olympics" title="2002 Winter Olympics">2002 Winter Olympics</a> in Salt Lake City, Utah. Departing from previous practice, he stood among a group of U.S. athletes rather than from a ceremonial stand or box, saying: "On behalf of a proud, determined, and grateful nation, I declare open the Games of Salt Lake City, celebrating the Olympic Winter Games."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[318]</a></sup> In 2008, in the course of a good-will trip to Asia, he attended the <a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics" title="2008 Summer Olympics">Summer Olympics</a> in Beijing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319">[319]</a></sup></p>
<p>Bush twice invoked <a href="/wiki/Twenty-fifth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution#Section_3:_Presidential_declaration" title="Twenty-fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution">Section 3 of the Twenty-fifth Amendment</a>, which allows a President to temporarily transfer the powers and duties of his office to the Vice President who then becomes <a href="/wiki/Acting_President_of_the_United_States" title="Acting President of the United States">Acting President</a>. On June 29, 2002, Bush underwent a colonoscopy and chose to invoke Section 3 of the amendment, making Vice President <a href="/wiki/Dick_Cheney" title="Dick Cheney">Dick Cheney</a> the Acting President. The medical procedure began at 7:09 am. EDT and ended at 7:29 am. EDT. Bush woke up twenty minutes later, but did not resume his presidential powers and duties until 9:24 am. EDT after the president's doctor, <a href="/wiki/Richard_Tubb" title="Richard Tubb">Richard Tubb</a>, conducted an overall examination. Tubb said he recommended the additional time to make sure the sedative had no after effects. On July 21, 2007, Bush again invoked Section 3 in response to having to undergo a colonoscopy, again making Vice President Cheney the Acting President. Bush invoked Section 3 at 7:16 am. EDT. He reclaimed his powers at 9:21 am. EDT. In both cases, Bush specifically cited Section 3 when he transferred the Presidential powers to the Vice President and when he reclaimed those powers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[320]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Judicial_appointments">Judicial appointments</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Supreme_Court">Supreme Court</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush_Supreme_Court_candidates" title="George W. Bush Supreme Court candidates">George W. Bush Supreme Court candidates</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Roberts,_Bush_SCOTUS_announcement.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="365" data-file-width="515" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Roberts%2C_Bush_SCOTUS_announcement.jpg/220px-Roberts%2C_Bush_SCOTUS_announcement.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Roberts%2C_Bush_SCOTUS_announcement.jpg/330px-Roberts%2C_Bush_SCOTUS_announcement.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Roberts%2C_Bush_SCOTUS_announcement.jpg/440px-Roberts%2C_Bush_SCOTUS_announcement.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Roberts,_Bush_SCOTUS_announcement.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Supreme Court Justice nominee John Roberts and President Bush, July 19, 2005</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Following the announcement of <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States" title="Supreme Court of the United States">Supreme Court</a> Justice <a href="/wiki/Sandra_Day_O%27Connor" title="Sandra Day O'Connor">Sandra Day O'Connor</a>'s retirement on July 1, 2005, Bush nominated <a href="/wiki/John_Roberts" title="John Roberts">John Roberts</a> to succeed her. On September 5, following the death of <a href="/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_the_United_States" title="Chief Justice of the United States">Chief Justice</a> <a href="/wiki/William_Rehnquist" title="William Rehnquist">William Rehnquist</a>, this nomination was withdrawn and Bush instead nominated Roberts for Chief Justice to succeed Rehnquist. Roberts was confirmed by the Senate as the 17th Chief Justice on September 29, 2005.</p>
<p>On October 3, 2005, Bush nominated long time White House Counsel <a href="/wiki/Harriet_Miers" title="Harriet Miers">Harriet Miers</a> for O'Connor's position. After facing significant opposition from both parties, who found her to be ill-prepared and uninformed on the law,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Greenburg.2C_Jan_Crawford_2007._Page_278_321-0"><a href="#cite_note-Greenburg.2C_Jan_Crawford_2007._Page_278-321">[321]</a></sup> Miers asked that her name be withdrawn on October 27. Four days later, on October 31, Bush nominated federal appellate judge <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Alito" title="Samuel Alito">Samuel Alito</a>. Alito was confirmed as the 110th Supreme Court Justice on January 31, 2006.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[322]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_courts">Other courts</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_federal_judges_appointed_by_George_W._Bush" title="List of federal judges appointed by George W. Bush">List of federal judges appointed by George W. Bush</a></div>
<p>In addition to his two Supreme Court appointments, Bush appointed 61 judges to the <a href="/wiki/United_States_courts_of_appeals" title="United States courts of appeals">United States courts of appeals</a> and 261 judges to the <a href="/wiki/United_States_district_court" title="United States district court">United States district courts</a>. Each of these numbers, along with his total of 324 judicial appointments, is third in American history, behind both <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bill_Clinton" title="Bill Clinton">Bill Clinton</a>. Bush experienced a number of <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush_judicial_appointment_controversies" title="George W. Bush judicial appointment controversies">judicial appointment controversies</a>. Debate during one confirmation session lasted "39 stupefying hours" according to <i>The New York Times</i>. On August 3, 2001, the Senate did not consent to keep existing nominations in <i>status quo</i>, returning 40 judicial nominations, and 164 total nominations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[323]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[324]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325"><a href="#cite_note-325">[325]</a></sup></p>
<p>At the outset, Judicature magazine noted that the "Senate Democrats were gearing up for the approaching confirmation hearings" before the first set of nominees were sent to the Senate. It then cites <i>The New York Times</i> as saying "Senate Democrats have pledged they will not automatically vote to confirm Mr. Bush's judicial nominees and will subject them to intense scrutiny."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326"><a href="#cite_note-326">[326]</a></sup></p>
<p>The Senate confirmed only 8 out of 60 judicial nominations by October 2001. In February 2003, the Democrats successfully filibustered the nomination of <a href="/wiki/Miguel_Estrada" title="Miguel Estrada">Miguel Estrada</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[327]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cultural_and_political_image">Cultural and political image</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Domestic">Domestic</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Public_image_of_George_W._Bush" title="Public image of George W. Bush">Public image of George W. Bush</a></div>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Efforts_to_impeach_George_W._Bush" title="Efforts to impeach George W. Bush">Efforts to impeach George W. Bush</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:George_W_Bush_approval_ratings.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="585" data-file-width="1155" height="111" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/George_W_Bush_approval_ratings.svg/220px-George_W_Bush_approval_ratings.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/George_W_Bush_approval_ratings.svg/330px-George_W_Bush_approval_ratings.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/George_W_Bush_approval_ratings.svg/440px-George_W_Bush_approval_ratings.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:George_W_Bush_approval_ratings.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #4A7EBB; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;"> </span> approve</div>
<div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #BE4B48; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;"> </span> disapprove</div>
<div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #98B954; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;"> </span> unsure</div>
<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gallup_poll" title="Gallup poll">Gallup</a>/<i><a href="/wiki/USA_Today" title="USA Today">USA Today</a></i> Bush public opinion polling from February 2001 to January 2009.</div>
</div>
</div>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Image">Image</span></h5>
<p>Bush's upbringing in <a href="/wiki/West_Texas" title="West Texas">West Texas</a>, his accent, his <a href="/wiki/United_States_Presidential_vacations" title="United States Presidential vacations">vacations</a> on his Texas ranch, and his penchant for country metaphors contribute to his folksy, American <a href="/wiki/Cowboy" title="Cowboy">cowboy</a> image.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[328]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBCcowboy_329-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBCcowboy-329">[329]</a></sup> "I think people look at him and think <a href="/wiki/John_Wayne" title="John Wayne">John Wayne</a>," said <a href="/wiki/Piers_Morgan" title="Piers Morgan">Piers Morgan</a>, editor of the British <i><a href="/wiki/Daily_Mirror" title="Daily Mirror">Daily Mirror</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[330]</a></sup> It has been suggested that Bush's accent was an active choice, as a way of distinguishing himself from Northeastern intellectuals and anchoring himself to his Texas roots.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331"><a href="#cite_note-331">[331]</a></sup> Both supporters and detractors have pointed to his country persona as reasons for their support or criticism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBCcowboy_329-1"><a href="#cite_note-BBCcowboy-329">[329]</a></sup></p>
<p>Bush has been <a href="/wiki/Parody" title="Parody">parodied</a> by the media,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[332]</a></sup> comedians, and other politicians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[333]</a></sup> Detractors tended to cite linguistic errors made by Bush during his public speeches, which are colloquially referred to as <a href="/wiki/Bushism" title="Bushism">Bushisms</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334"><a href="#cite_note-334">[334]</a></sup> Some pundits labeled Bush "the worst president ever".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335"><a href="#cite_note-335">[335]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336">[336]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337"><a href="#cite_note-337">[337]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[338]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[339]</a></sup> In contrast to his father, who was perceived as having troubles with an overarching unifying theme, Bush embraced larger visions and was seen as a man of larger ideas and associated huge risks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[340]</a></sup> Tony Blair wrote in 2010 that the caricature of Bush as being dumb is "ludicrous" and that Bush is "very smart".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341"><a href="#cite_note-341">[341]</a></sup> In an interview with <i><a href="/wiki/Playboy" title="Playboy">Playboy</a></i>, <i>New York Times</i> columnist <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/David_Brooks_(journalist)" title="David Brooks (journalist)">David Brooks</a> said George W. Bush "was 60 IQ points smarter in private than he was in public. He doesn't want anybody to think he's smarter than they are, so puts on a Texas act."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rogers2012_342-0"><a href="#cite_note-rogers2012-342">[342]</a></sup></p>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Job_approval">Job approval</span></h5>
<p>Bush began his presidency with <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_approval_rating" title="United States presidential approval rating">approval ratings</a> near 50 percent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ApprovalRatingsOverTime_343-0"><a href="#cite_note-ApprovalRatingsOverTime-343">[343]</a></sup> After the <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">September 11 attacks</a>, Bush gained an approval rating of 90 percent,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[344]</a></sup> maintaining 80 to 90 percent approval for four months after the attacks. It remained over 50 percent during most of his first term<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gallup_12-1"><a href="#cite_note-Gallup-12">[12]</a></sup> and then fell to as low as 19 percent in his second term.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jobapp19_345-0"><a href="#cite_note-jobapp19-345">[345]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 2000 and again in 2004, <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time</a></i> magazine named George W. Bush as its <a href="/wiki/Time_Person_of_the_Year" title="Time Person of the Year">Person of the Year</a>, a title awarded to someone who the editors believe "has done the most to influence the events of the year".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[346]</a></sup> In May 2004, <a href="/wiki/Gallup_(company)" title="Gallup (company)">Gallup</a> reported that 89 percent of the Republican electorate approved of Bush.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[347]</a></sup> However, the support waned due mostly to a minority of Republicans' frustration with him on issues of spending, illegal immigration, and <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle Eastern</a> affairs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348">[348]</a></sup></p>
<p>Within the United States armed forces, according to an unscientific survey, the president was strongly supported in the 2004 presidential elections.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-military_support_349-0"><a href="#cite_note-military_support-349">[349]</a></sup> While 73 percent of military personnel said that they would vote for Bush, 18 percent preferred his Democratic rival, <a href="/wiki/John_Kerry" title="John Kerry">John Kerry</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-military_support_349-1"><a href="#cite_note-military_support-349">[349]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Peter_Feaver" title="Peter Feaver">Peter Feaver</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Duke_University" title="Duke University">Duke University</a> political scientist who has studied the political leanings of the U.S. military, members of the armed services supported Bush because they found him more likely than Kerry to complete the War in Iraq.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-military_support_349-2"><a href="#cite_note-military_support-349">[349]</a></sup></p>
<p>Bush's approval rating went below the 50 percent mark in <a href="/wiki/Associated_Press" title="Associated Press">AP</a>-<a href="/wiki/Ipsos" title="Ipsos">Ipsos</a> polling in December 2004.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Taipei_Times_350-0"><a href="#cite_note-Taipei_Times-350">[350]</a></sup> Thereafter, his approval ratings and approval of his handling of domestic and foreign policy issues steadily dropped. Bush received heavy criticism for his handling of the <a href="/wiki/Iraq_War" title="Iraq War">Iraq War</a>, his <a href="/wiki/Political_effects_of_Hurricane_Katrina" title="Political effects of Hurricane Katrina">response to Hurricane Katrina</a> and to the <a href="/wiki/Abu_Ghraib_torture_and_prisoner_abuse" title="Abu Ghraib torture and prisoner abuse">Abu Ghraib prisoner abuse</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NSA_warrantless_surveillance" title="NSA warrantless surveillance">NSA warrantless surveillance</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Plame_affair" title="Plame affair">Plame affair</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Guantanamo_Bay_detention_camp" title="Guantanamo Bay detention camp">Guantanamo Bay detention camp</a> controversies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Unchecked_and_Unbalanced_351-0"><a href="#cite_note-Unchecked_and_Unbalanced-351">[351]</a></sup> There were calls for Bush's <a href="/wiki/Impeachment" title="Impeachment">impeachment</a>, though most polls showed a plurality of Americans would not support such an action.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[352]</a></sup> The arguments offered for impeachment usually centered on the NSA warrantless surveillance controversy,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353"><a href="#cite_note-353">[353]</a></sup> the Bush administration's justification for the war in Iraq,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354"><a href="#cite_note-354">[354]</a></sup> and alleged violations of the <a href="/wiki/Geneva_Conventions" title="Geneva Conventions">Geneva Conventions</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355"><a href="#cite_note-355">[355]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives" title="United States House of Representatives">Representative</a> <a href="/wiki/Dennis_Kucinich" title="Dennis Kucinich">Dennis Kucinich</a> (D-<a href="/wiki/Ohio" title="Ohio">OH</a>), who had run against Bush during the 2004 presidential campaign, introduced 35 articles of impeachment on the floor of the House of Representatives against Bush on June 9, 2008, but <a href="/wiki/Speaker_of_the_United_States_House_of_Representatives" title="Speaker of the United States House of Representatives">Speaker</a> <a href="/wiki/Nancy_Pelosi" title="Nancy Pelosi">Nancy Pelosi</a> (D-<a href="/wiki/California" title="California">CA</a>) declared that impeachment was "off the table".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[356]</a></sup></p>
<p>Polls conducted in 2006 showed an average of 37 percent approval ratings for Bush,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[357]</a></sup> the lowest for any second-term president at that point of his term since <a href="/wiki/Harry_S._Truman" title="Harry S. Truman">Harry S. Truman</a> in March 1951 (when Truman's approval rating was 28 percent),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Taipei_Times_350-1"><a href="#cite_note-Taipei_Times-350">[350]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[358]</a></sup> which contributed to what Bush called the "thumping" of the Republican Party in the <a href="/wiki/United_States_elections,_2006" title="United States elections, 2006">2006 mid-term elections</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[359]</a></sup> Throughout most of 2007, Bush's approval rating hovered in the mid-thirties;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360"><a href="#cite_note-360">[360]</a></sup> the average for his entire second term was 37 percent, according to Gallup.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[361]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:George_W_Bush_approval_ratings_with_events.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="435" data-file-width="742" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/George_W_Bush_approval_ratings_with_events.svg/220px-George_W_Bush_approval_ratings_with_events.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/George_W_Bush_approval_ratings_with_events.svg/330px-George_W_Bush_approval_ratings_with_events.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/George_W_Bush_approval_ratings_with_events.svg/440px-George_W_Bush_approval_ratings_with_events.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:George_W_Bush_approval_ratings_with_events.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
President Bush's approval rating with key events marked, 2001–2006</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>By the beginning of 2008, his final year in office, Bush's approval rating had dropped to a low of just 19 percent, largely from the loss of support among Republicans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jobapp19_345-1"><a href="#cite_note-jobapp19-345">[345]</a></sup> Commenting on his low poll numbers and accusations of being "the worst president,"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362"><a href="#cite_note-362">[362]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363"><a href="#cite_note-363">[363]</a></sup> Bush would say, "I make decisions on what I think is right for the United States based upon principles. I frankly don't give a damn about the polls."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fox_News_364-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fox_News-364">[364]</a></sup></p>
<p>In the spring of that year, Bush's disapproval ratings reached the highest ever recorded for any president in the 70-year history of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gallup_poll" title="Gallup poll">Gallup poll</a>, with 69 percent of those polled in April 2008 disapproving of the job Bush was doing as president and 28 percent approving—although the majority (66 percent) of Republicans still approved of his job performance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USAToday_April_21.2C_2008-bushrating_365-0"><a href="#cite_note-USAToday_April_21.2C_2008-bushrating-365">[365]</a></sup></p>
<p>In polls conducted in the fall, just before the 2008 election, his approval ratings remained at record lows of 19 to 20 percent,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CBSNYTfinalpolls_366-0"><a href="#cite_note-CBSNYTfinalpolls-366">[366]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ARGbushpolls_367-0"><a href="#cite_note-ARGbushpolls-367">[367]</a></sup> while his disapproval ratings ranged from 67 percent to as high as 75 percent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ARGbushpolls_367-1"><a href="#cite_note-ARGbushpolls-367">[367]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[368]</a></sup> In polling conducted January 9–11, 2009, his final job approval rating by Gallup was 34 percent, which placed him on par with <a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Carter" title="Jimmy Carter">Jimmy Carter</a> and <a href="/wiki/Harry_S._Truman" title="Harry S. Truman">Harry S. Truman</a>, the other presidents whose final Gallup ratings measured in the low 30s (<a href="/wiki/Richard_Nixon" title="Richard Nixon">Richard Nixon</a>'s final Gallup approval rating was even lower, at 24 percent).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-saadgall_369-0"><a href="#cite_note-saadgall-369">[369]</a></sup> According to a <a href="/wiki/CBS_News" title="CBS News">CBS News</a>/<i>New York Times</i> poll conducted January 11–15, 2009, Bush's final approval rating in office was 22 percent, the lowest in American history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CBSNYTfinalpolls_366-1"><a href="#cite_note-CBSNYTfinalpolls-366">[366]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_perceptions">Foreign perceptions</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2006_Musharaff_at_the_White_House.jpeg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="350" data-file-width="514" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/2006_Musharaff_at_the_White_House.jpeg/220px-2006_Musharaff_at_the_White_House.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/2006_Musharaff_at_the_White_House.jpeg/330px-2006_Musharaff_at_the_White_House.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/2006_Musharaff_at_the_White_House.jpeg/440px-2006_Musharaff_at_the_White_House.jpeg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2006_Musharaff_at_the_White_House.jpeg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
President Bush with President <a href="/wiki/Pervez_Musharraf" title="Pervez Musharraf">Pervez Musharraf</a> of the Islamic Republic of Pakistan, September 22, 2006</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Bush was criticized internationally and targeted by the global anti-war and anti-globalization campaigns for his administration's foreign policy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[370]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[371]</a></sup> Views of him within the <a href="/wiki/International_community" title="International community">international community</a>—even in France, a close ally of the United States—were more negative than those of most previous American presidents in history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[372]</a></sup></p>
<p>Bush was described as having especially close personal relationships with Tony Blair of Great Britain and <a href="/wiki/Vicente_Fox" title="Vicente Fox">Vicente Fox</a> of Mexico, although formal relations were sometimes strained.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[373]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[374]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[375]</a></sup> Other leaders, such as Afghan president <a href="/wiki/Hamid_Karzai" title="Hamid Karzai">Hamid Karzai</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376"><a href="#cite_note-376">[376]</a></sup> Ugandan president <a href="/wiki/Yoweri_Museveni" title="Yoweri Museveni">Yoweri Museveni</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377"><a href="#cite_note-377">[377]</a></sup> Spanish prime minister <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Luis_Rodr%C3%ADguez_Zapatero" title="José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero">José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[378]</a></sup> and Venezuelan president <a href="/wiki/Hugo_Ch%C3%A1vez" title="Hugo Chávez">Hugo Chávez</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379"><a href="#cite_note-379">[379]</a></sup> openly criticized the president. Later in Bush's presidency, tensions arose between him and <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a>, which led to a cooling of their relationship.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LeeryofPutin_380-0"><a href="#cite_note-LeeryofPutin-380">[380]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:UK_Anti_Bush_visit_protest.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3888" data-file-width="2588" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/UK_Anti_Bush_visit_protest.jpg/170px-UK_Anti_Bush_visit_protest.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/UK_Anti_Bush_visit_protest.jpg/255px-UK_Anti_Bush_visit_protest.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/UK_Anti_Bush_visit_protest.jpg/340px-UK_Anti_Bush_visit_protest.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:UK_Anti_Bush_visit_protest.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Anti-war demonstration during President Bush's visit to London, June 2008</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>In 2006, most respondents in 18 of 21 countries surveyed around the world were found to hold an unfavorable opinion of Bush. Respondents indicated that they judged his administration as negative for world security.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[381]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[382]</a></sup> In 2007, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pew_Global_Attitudes_Project" title="Pew Global Attitudes Project">Pew Global Attitudes Project</a> reported that during the Bush presidency, attitudes towards the United States, and towards Americans, became less favorable around the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[383]</a></sup></p>
<p>A March 2007 survey of Arab opinion conducted by Zogby International and the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Maryland,_College_Park" title="University of Maryland, College Park">University of Maryland</a> found that Bush was the most disliked leader in the Arab world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[384]</a></sup></p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Pew_Research_Center" title="Pew Research Center">Pew Research Center</a>'s 2007 Global Attitudes poll found that out of 47 countries, in only nine countries did most respondents express "a lot of confidence" or "some confidence" in Bush: Ethiopia, Ghana, India, Israel, Ivory Coast, Kenya, Mali, Nigeria, and Uganda.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pew_research_385-0"><a href="#cite_note-pew_research-385">[385]</a></sup></p>
<p>During a June 2007 visit to the predominantly Muslim<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[386]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Albania" title="Albania">Albania</a>, Bush was greeted enthusiastically. Albania has a population of 2.8 million,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387">[387]</a></sup> has troops in both Iraq and Afghanistan, and the country's government is highly supportive of American foreign policy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-albania_388-0"><a href="#cite_note-albania-388">[388]</a></sup> A huge image of the President was hung in the middle of the capital city of <a href="/wiki/Tirana" title="Tirana">Tirana</a> flanked by Albanian and American flags while a local street was named after him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389"><a href="#cite_note-389">[389]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390"><a href="#cite_note-390">[390]</a></sup> A shirt-sleeved statue of Bush was unveiled in <a href="/wiki/Fush%C3%AB-Kruj%C3%AB" title="Fushë-Krujë">Fushë-Krujë</a>, a few kilometers northwest of <a href="/wiki/Tirana" title="Tirana">Tirana</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[391]</a></sup> The Bush administration's support for the independence of Albanian-majority Kosovo, while endearing him to the <a href="/wiki/Albanians" title="Albanians">Albanians</a>, has troubled U.S. relations with Serbia, leading to the February 2008 torching of the U.S. embassy in <a href="/wiki/Belgrade" title="Belgrade">Belgrade</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[392]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Acknowledgments_and_dedications">Acknowledgments and dedications</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Statue_G.W.Busch_at_Fush%C3%AB-Kruja.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2272" data-file-width="1704" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Statue_G.W.Busch_at_Fush%C3%AB-Kruja.JPG/170px-Statue_G.W.Busch_at_Fush%C3%AB-Kruja.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Statue_G.W.Busch_at_Fush%C3%AB-Kruja.JPG/255px-Statue_G.W.Busch_at_Fush%C3%AB-Kruja.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Statue_G.W.Busch_at_Fush%C3%AB-Kruja.JPG/340px-Statue_G.W.Busch_at_Fush%C3%AB-Kruja.JPG 2x" width="170"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Statue_G.W.Busch_at_Fush%C3%AB-Kruja.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The statue of George W. Bush was erected at <a href="/wiki/Fush%C3%AB-Kruj%C3%AB" title="Fushë-Krujë">Fushë-Krujë</a>, Albania after his visit</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>On May 7, 2005, during an official state visit to Latvia, Bush was awarded the <a href="/wiki/Order_of_the_Three_Stars" title="Order of the Three Stars">Order of the Three Stars</a> presented to him by President <a href="/wiki/Vaira_V%C4%AB%C4%B7e-Freiberga" title="Vaira Vīķe-Freiberga">Vaira Vīķe-Freiberga</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LatPres_393-0"><a href="#cite_note-LatPres-393">[393]</a></sup> A few places outside the United States bear Bush's name. In 2005, the <a href="/wiki/Tbilisi" title="Tbilisi">Tbilisi</a> City Council voted to rename a street in honor of the U.S. president.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Civil.ge_394-0"><a href="#cite_note-Civil.ge-394">[394]</a></sup> Previously known as Melaani Drive, the street links the <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgian</a> capital's airport with the city center and was used by Bush's motorcade during his visit four months earlier.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tampa_times_395-0"><a href="#cite_note-tampa_times-395">[395]</a></sup> A street in <a href="/wiki/Tirana" title="Tirana">Tirana</a>, formerly known as <i>Rruga Puntorët e Rilendjes</i>, situated directly outside the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Albania" title="Parliament of Albania">Albanian Parliament</a>, was renamed after Bush a few days before he made the first-ever visit by an American president to Albania in June 2007.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[396]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>, a small plaza with a monument bearing his name is also dedicated to Bush.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[397]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 2012, Estonian President <a href="/wiki/Toomas_Hendrik_Ilves" title="Toomas Hendrik Ilves">Toomas Hendrik Ilves</a> awarded Bush the <a href="/wiki/Order_of_the_Cross_of_Terra_Mariana" title="Order of the Cross of Terra Mariana">Order of the Cross of Terra Mariana</a> for his work in expanding NATO.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[398]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Reception">Reception</span></h3>
<p>The George W. Bush presidency has been ranked among the worst in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Historical_rankings_of_Presidents_of_the_United_States" title="Historical rankings of Presidents of the United States">surveys of presidential scholars</a> published in the late 2000s and 2010s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-US_News_14-1"><a href="#cite_note-US_News-14">[14]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Austin_15-1"><a href="#cite_note-Austin-15">[15]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mann_16-1"><a href="#cite_note-Mann-16">[16]</a></sup></p>
<p>After his re-election in 2004, Bush received increasingly heated <a href="/wiki/Public_image_of_George_W._Bush" title="Public image of George W. Bush">criticism</a> from across the <a href="/wiki/Political_spectrum" title="Political spectrum">political spectrum</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Republican_right_abandoning_Bush_6-1"><a href="#cite_note-Republican_right_abandoning_Bush-6">[6]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kelley_Beaucar_Vlahos_7-1"><a href="#cite_note-Kelley_Beaucar_Vlahos-7">[7]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Baker_8-1"><a href="#cite_note-Baker-8">[8]</a></sup> for his handling of the Iraq War, <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Katrina" title="Hurricane Katrina">Hurricane Katrina</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TVNZ_9-1"><a href="#cite_note-TVNZ-9">[9]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mike_M._Ahlers_10-1"><a href="#cite_note-Mike_M._Ahlers-10">[10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_11-1"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-11">[11]</a></sup> and other challenges. Amid this criticism, the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)" title="Democratic Party (United States)">Democratic Party</a> regained control of Congress in the <a href="/wiki/United_States_elections,_2006" title="United States elections, 2006">2006 elections</a>. In December 2007, the United States entered its longest post-<a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> recession, often referred to as the "<a href="/wiki/Great_Recession" title="Great Recession">Great Recession</a>", prompting the Bush administration to obtain congressional passage of multiple economic programs intended to preserve the country's financial system. Nationally, Bush was both one of the most popular and unpopular presidents in history, having received the highest recorded presidential approval ratings in the wake of the September 11 attacks, as well as one of the lowest approval ratings during the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%9308" title="Financial crisis of 2007–08">2008 financial crisis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gallup_12-2"><a href="#cite_note-Gallup-12">[12]</a></sup></p>
<p>For his part, Bush said in 2013, "Ultimately history will judge the decisions I made, and I won't be around because it will take time for the objective historians to show up. So I am pretty comfortable with it. I did what I did."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[399]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Post-presidency">Post-presidency</span></h2>
<h3><span id="Residence_(2009–present)"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Residence_.282009.E2.80.93present.29">Residence (2009–present)</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:George_%26_Laura_Bush_board_Air_Force_One_1-20-09_hires_091220-F-0194C-001a.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="855" data-file-width="1282" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/George_%26_Laura_Bush_board_Air_Force_One_1-20-09_hires_091220-F-0194C-001a.jpg/220px-George_%26_Laura_Bush_board_Air_Force_One_1-20-09_hires_091220-F-0194C-001a.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/George_%26_Laura_Bush_board_Air_Force_One_1-20-09_hires_091220-F-0194C-001a.jpg/330px-George_%26_Laura_Bush_board_Air_Force_One_1-20-09_hires_091220-F-0194C-001a.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/George_%26_Laura_Bush_board_Air_Force_One_1-20-09_hires_091220-F-0194C-001a.jpg/440px-George_%26_Laura_Bush_board_Air_Force_One_1-20-09_hires_091220-F-0194C-001a.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:George_%26_Laura_Bush_board_Air_Force_One_1-20-09_hires_091220-F-0194C-001a.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
George and Laura Bush waving to a crowd of 1000 at <a href="/wiki/Andrews_Air_Force_Base" title="Andrews Air Force Base">Andrews Air Force Base</a> before their final departure to Texas, January 20, 2009</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Following the <a href="/wiki/First_inauguration_of_Barack_Obama" title="First inauguration of Barack Obama">inauguration of Barack Obama</a>, Bush and his family flew from <a href="/wiki/Andrews_Air_Force_Base" title="Andrews Air Force Base">Andrews Air Force Base</a> to a homecoming celebration in <a href="/wiki/Midland,_Texas" title="Midland, Texas">Midland, Texas</a>, following which they returned to their ranch in <a href="/wiki/Crawford,_Texas" title="Crawford, Texas">Crawford, Texas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-leaving_400-0"><a href="#cite_note-leaving-400">[400]</a></sup> They bought a home in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Preston_Hollow" title="Preston Hollow">Preston Hollow</a> neighborhood of <a href="/wiki/Dallas" title="Dallas">Dallas</a>, Texas, where they settled down.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[401]</a></sup></p>
<p>He makes regular appearances at various events throughout the Dallas/Fort Worth area, most notably when he conducted the opening coin toss at the <a href="/wiki/Dallas_Cowboys" title="Dallas Cowboys">Dallas Cowboys</a> first game in the team's new <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cowboys_Stadium" title="Cowboys Stadium">stadium</a> in <a href="/wiki/Arlington,_Texas" title="Arlington, Texas">Arlington</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[402]</a></sup> and an April 2009 visit to a <a href="/wiki/Texas_Rangers_(baseball)" title="Texas Rangers (baseball)">Texas Rangers</a> game, where he thanked the people of Dallas for helping him settle in and was met with a standing ovation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403"><a href="#cite_note-403">[403]</a></sup> He also attended every home playoff game for the <a href="/wiki/Texas_Rangers_(baseball)" title="Texas Rangers (baseball)">Texas Rangers</a> 2010 season and, accompanied by his father, threw out the ceremonial first pitch at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rangers_Ballpark_in_Arlington" title="Rangers Ballpark in Arlington">Rangers Ballpark in Arlington</a> for Game 4 of the <a href="/wiki/2010_World_Series" title="2010 World Series">2010 World Series</a> on October 31, 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404">[404]</a></sup></p>
<p>On August 6, 2013, Bush was successfully treated for a <a href="/wiki/Coronary_artery_disease" title="Coronary artery disease">coronary artery blockage</a> with a <a href="/wiki/Coronary_stent" title="Coronary stent">stent</a>. The blockage had been found during an <a href="/wiki/General_medical_examination" title="General medical examination">annual medical examination</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[405]</a></sup></p>
<p>In reaction to the <a href="/wiki/2016_shooting_of_Dallas_police_officers" title="2016 shooting of Dallas police officers">2016 shooting of Dallas police officers</a>, Bush stated: "Laura and I are heartbroken by the heinous acts of violence in our city last night. Murdering the innocent is always evil, never more so than when the lives taken belong to those who protect our families and communities."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[406]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Publications_and_appearances">Publications and appearances</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Obama,_Bush,_and_Clinton_discuss_the_2010_Haiti_earthquake.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1962" data-file-width="2768" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Obama%2C_Bush%2C_and_Clinton_discuss_the_2010_Haiti_earthquake.jpg/220px-Obama%2C_Bush%2C_and_Clinton_discuss_the_2010_Haiti_earthquake.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Obama%2C_Bush%2C_and_Clinton_discuss_the_2010_Haiti_earthquake.jpg/330px-Obama%2C_Bush%2C_and_Clinton_discuss_the_2010_Haiti_earthquake.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Obama%2C_Bush%2C_and_Clinton_discuss_the_2010_Haiti_earthquake.jpg/440px-Obama%2C_Bush%2C_and_Clinton_discuss_the_2010_Haiti_earthquake.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Obama,_Bush,_and_Clinton_discuss_the_2010_Haiti_earthquake.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
George W. Bush, President Obama, and Bill Clinton meeting in the Oval Office, January 16, 2010</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Since leaving office, Bush has kept a relatively low profile<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407"><a href="#cite_note-407">[407]</a></sup> though he has made public appearances, most notably after the release of his memoirs in 2010 and for the 10th anniversary of the <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">September 11 attacks</a> in 2011. In March 2009, he delivered his first post-presidency speech in <a href="/wiki/Calgary" title="Calgary">Calgary</a>, Alberta,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408">[408]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[409]</a></sup> appeared via video on <i><a href="/wiki/The_Colbert_Report" title="The Colbert Report">The Colbert Report</a></i> during which he praised U.S. troops for earning a "special place in American history,"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410">[410]</a></sup> and attended the funeral of Senator <a href="/wiki/Ted_Kennedy" title="Ted Kennedy">Ted Kennedy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pols_411-0"><a href="#cite_note-pols-411">[411]</a></sup> Bush made his debut as a motivational speaker on October 26 at the "Get Motivated" seminar in Dallas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412">[412]</a></sup> In the aftermath of the <a href="/wiki/2009_Fort_Hood_shooting" title="2009 Fort Hood shooting">Fort Hood shooting</a> that took place on November 5, 2009, in Texas, the Bushes paid an undisclosed visit to the survivors and victims' families the day following the shooting, having contacted the base commander requesting that the visit be private and not involve press coverage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413"><a href="#cite_note-413">[413]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Charlie_Strong_with_George_W._Bush_and_Jesse_Jackson.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3840" data-file-width="5760" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Charlie_Strong_with_George_W._Bush_and_Jesse_Jackson.jpg/220px-Charlie_Strong_with_George_W._Bush_and_Jesse_Jackson.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Charlie_Strong_with_George_W._Bush_and_Jesse_Jackson.jpg/330px-Charlie_Strong_with_George_W._Bush_and_Jesse_Jackson.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Charlie_Strong_with_George_W._Bush_and_Jesse_Jackson.jpg/440px-Charlie_Strong_with_George_W._Bush_and_Jesse_Jackson.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Charlie_Strong_with_George_W._Bush_and_Jesse_Jackson.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
(L–R) <a href="/wiki/Charlie_Strong" title="Charlie Strong">Charlie Strong</a>, Texas Longhorns head football coach, George W. Bush and Reverend <a href="/wiki/Jesse_Jackson" title="Jesse Jackson">Jesse Jackson</a> hold up a <a href="/wiki/Texas_Longhorns_football" title="Texas Longhorns football">Texas Longhorns football</a> jersey at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/LBJ_Presidential_Library" title="LBJ Presidential Library">LBJ Presidential Library</a> in 2014</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Bush released his memoirs, <i><a href="/wiki/Decision_Points" title="Decision Points">Decision Points</a></i>, on November 9, 2010. During a pre-release appearance promoting the book, Bush said he considered his biggest accomplishment to be keeping "the country safe amid a real danger", and his greatest failure to be his inability to secure the passage of <a href="/wiki/Social_Security_debate_in_the_United_States" title="Social Security debate in the United States">Social Security reform</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[414]</a></sup> He also made news defending his administration's enhanced interrogation techniques, specifically the <a href="/wiki/Waterboarding" title="Waterboarding">waterboarding</a> of <a href="/wiki/Khalid_Sheikh_Mohammed" title="Khalid Sheikh Mohammed">Khalid Sheikh Mohammed</a>, saying, "I'd do it again to save lives."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[415]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 2012, he wrote the foreword of <i><a href="/wiki/The_4%25_Solution:_Unleashing_the_Economic_Growth_America_Needs" title="The 4% Solution: Unleashing the Economic Growth America Needs">The 4% Solution: Unleashing the Economic Growth America Needs</a></i>, an economics book published by the <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush_Presidential_Center" title="George W. Bush Presidential Center">George W. Bush Presidential Center</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lubbockfourpercent_416-0"><a href="#cite_note-lubbockfourpercent-416">[416]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-soniasmithfourpercent_417-0"><a href="#cite_note-soniasmithfourpercent-417">[417]</a></sup> He also presented the book at the <a href="/wiki/Parkland_Memorial_Hospital" title="Parkland Memorial Hospital">Parkland Memorial Hospital</a> in Dallas, Texas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-booktvfourpercent_418-0"><a href="#cite_note-booktvfourpercent-418">[418]</a></sup></p>
<p>Bush appeared on <a href="/wiki/NBC" title="NBC">NBC</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/The_Tonight_Show_with_Jay_Leno" title="The Tonight Show with Jay Leno">The Tonight Show with Jay Leno</a></i> on November 19, 2013, along with the former <a href="/wiki/First_Lady" title="First Lady">First Lady</a>, Laura Bush. When asked by Leno why he does not comment publicly about the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Obama_administration" title="Obama administration">Obama administration</a>, Bush said, "I don't think it's good for the country to have a former president criticize his successor."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419"><a href="#cite_note-419">[419]</a></sup> Despite this statement, on Saturday, April 25, 2015, Bush criticized President <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> at a meeting of the <a href="/wiki/Republican_Jewish_Coalition" title="Republican Jewish Coalition">Republican Jewish Coalition</a> at the <a href="/wiki/The_Venetian_Las_Vegas" title="The Venetian Las Vegas">Venetian Hotel</a> in Las Vegas. Bush criticized Obama's handling of Iran, specifically with respect to sanctions and a nuclear deal, saying: "You think the Middle East is chaotic now? Imagine what it looks like for our grandchildren. That's how Americans should view the deal." Bush also attacked Obama's withdrawal of U.S. troops from Iraq in 2011, calling it a "strategic blunder", borrowing a term that had been used by South Carolina Senator <a href="/wiki/Lindsey_Graham" title="Lindsey Graham">Lindsey Graham</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[420]</a></sup></p>
<p>Alongside the 2014 <a href="/wiki/United_States%E2%80%93Africa_Leaders_Summit" title="United States–Africa Leaders Summit">United States–Africa Leaders Summit</a>, Bush, <a href="/wiki/Michelle_Obama" title="Michelle Obama">Michelle Obama</a>, the State Department, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/George_W._Bush_Institute" title="George W. Bush Institute">George W. Bush Institute</a> hosted a daylong forum on education and health with the spouses of the African leaders attending the summit. Bush urged African leaders to avoid discriminatory laws that make the treatment of <a href="/wiki/HIV/AIDS" title="HIV/AIDS">HIV/AIDS</a> more difficult.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[421]</a></sup></p>
<p>Bush has spoken in favor of increased global participation of women in politics and societal matters in foreign countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422"><a href="#cite_note-422">[422]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[423]</a></sup></p>
<p>On November 2, 2014, Bush spoke at an event to 200 business and civic leaders at the George W. Bush Presidential Library and Museum to raise awareness for the upcoming <a href="/wiki/Museum_of_the_Bible" title="Museum of the Bible">Museum of the Bible</a> in Washington D.C.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bushmuseumofthebible_39-1"><a href="#cite_note-bushmuseumofthebible-39">[39]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-424"><a href="#cite_note-424">[424]</a></sup></p>
<p>Bush published a <a href="/wiki/Biography" title="Biography">biography</a> of his father, <a href="/wiki/George_H._W._Bush" title="George H. W. Bush">George Bush</a>, called <i><a href="/wiki/41:_A_Portrait_of_My_Father" title="41: A Portrait of My Father">41: A Portrait of My Father</a></i>. It was released on November 11, 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-425"><a href="#cite_note-425">[425]</a></sup></p>
<p>In an interview published by <i><a href="/wiki/Israel_Hayom" title="Israel Hayom">Israel Hayom</a></i> magazine on June 12, 2015, Bush said that "boots on the ground" would be needed in order to defeat the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_State_of_Iraq_and_the_Levant" title="Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant">Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant</a> (ISIS). He added that people had said during his Presidency that he should withdraw American troops from Iraq, but he chose the opposite, sending 30,000 more troops in order to defeat <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Al_Qaeda_in_Iraq" title="Al Qaeda in Iraq">Al Qaeda in Iraq</a>, and that Al Qaeda in Iraq was defeated. Bush was also asked about Iran but declined to answer, stating that any answer he gives would be interpreted as undermining President <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IsraelHayom_426-0"><a href="#cite_note-IsraelHayom-426">[426]</a></sup></p>
<p>In February 2016, George W. Bush spoke and campaigned for his brother <a href="/wiki/Jeb_Bush" title="Jeb Bush">Jeb Bush</a> in South Carolina during a rally for the <a href="/wiki/Jeb_Bush_presidential_campaign,_2016" title="Jeb Bush presidential campaign, 2016">Jeb Bush presidential campaign</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_presidential_primaries,_2016" title="Republican Party presidential primaries, 2016">2016 Republican Party presidential primaries</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427"><a href="#cite_note-427">[427]</a></sup></p>
<p>While Bush endorsed the Republican Party's 2012 presidential nominee <a href="/wiki/Mitt_Romney" title="Mitt Romney">Mitt Romney</a>, he <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Republicans_opposing_Donald_Trump_presidential_campaign,_2016" title="List of Republicans opposing Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016">declined to endorse</a> the 2016 Republican nominee <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-428"><a href="#cite_note-428">[428]</a></sup> and he did not attend the <a href="/wiki/2016_Republican_National_Convention" title="2016 Republican National Convention">2016 Republican National Convention</a>, which formally nominated Trump.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-429"><a href="#cite_note-429">[429]</a></sup> On the eve of Trump's nomination, it was reported that Bush had privately expressed concern about the current direction of the Republican Party and told a group of his former aides and advisors, "I'm worried that I will be the last Republican president."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[430]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[431]</a></sup> Bush and his wife Laura did not vote for Trump in the <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2016" title="United States presidential election, 2016">2016 presidential election</a> according to a spokesperson for the Bush family, instead choosing to leave their presidential ballots blank.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-432"><a href="#cite_note-432">[432]</a></sup> After the election, Bush, his father, and his brother Jeb called Trump on the phone to congratulate him on his victory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-433"><a href="#cite_note-433">[433]</a></sup> Both he and Laura attended <a href="/wiki/Inauguration_of_Donald_Trump" title="Inauguration of Donald Trump">Trump's inauguration</a>, and images of Bush struggling to put on a rain <a href="/wiki/Poncho" title="Poncho">poncho</a> during the ceremony became an <a href="/wiki/Internet_meme" title="Internet meme">internet meme</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434"><a href="#cite_note-434">[434]</a></sup></p>
<p>In February 2017, Bush released a book of his own portraits of veterans called <i><a href="/wiki/Portraits_of_Courage" title="Portraits of Courage">Portraits of Courage</a></i> (full title: <i>Portraits of Courage: A Commander in Chief's Tribute to America's Warriors</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nbcpresidentwbush_435-0"><a href="#cite_note-nbcpresidentwbush-435">[435]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Collaborations">Collaborations</span></h3>
<p>In January 2010, at President Obama's request, Bush and Bill Clinton established the <a href="/wiki/Clinton_Bush_Haiti_Fund" title="Clinton Bush Haiti Fund">Clinton Bush Haiti Fund</a> to raise contributions for relief and recovery efforts following the <a href="/wiki/2010_Haiti_earthquake" title="2010 Haiti earthquake">2010 Haiti earthquake</a> earlier that month.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436"><a href="#cite_note-436">[436]</a></sup></p>
<p>On May 2, 2011, President Obama called Bush, who was at a restaurant with his wife, to inform him that <a href="/wiki/Death_of_Osama_bin_Laden" title="Death of Osama bin Laden">Osama bin Laden had been killed</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-437"><a href="#cite_note-437">[437]</a></sup> The Bushes joined the Obamas in New York City to mark the tenth anniversary of the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks. At the Ground Zero memorial, Bush read <a href="/wiki/Bixby_letter" title="Bixby letter">a letter</a> that President <a href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln" title="Abraham Lincoln">Abraham Lincoln</a> wrote to a widow who lost five sons during the Civil War.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-438"><a href="#cite_note-438">[438]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Art">Art</span></h3>
<p>After serving as president, Bush began <a href="/wiki/Painting" title="Painting">painting</a> as a <a href="/wiki/Hobby" title="Hobby">hobby</a> after reading <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Winston Churchill</a>'s essay "Painting as a Pastime". Subjects have included people, dogs, and <a href="/wiki/Still_life" title="Still life">still life</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-439"><a href="#cite_note-439">[439]</a></sup> He has also painted self-portraits and portraits of world leaders, including Vladimir Putin and Tony Blair.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-440"><a href="#cite_note-440">[440]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-441"><a href="#cite_note-441">[441]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442"><a href="#cite_note-442">[442]</a></sup> In February 2017, Bush released a book of portraits of veterans, <i><a href="/wiki/Portraits_of_Courage" title="Portraits of Courage">Portraits of Courage</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nbcpresidentwbush_435-1"><a href="#cite_note-nbcpresidentwbush-435">[435]</a></sup> The net proceeds from his book are donated to the <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush_Presidential_Center" title="George W. Bush Presidential Center">George W. Bush Presidential Center</a>.</p>
<p>Bill Arning, director of the <a href="/wiki/Contemporary_Arts_Museum_Houston" title="Contemporary Arts Museum Houston">Contemporary Arts Museum Houston</a>, called his portraits "thickly painted in what I would call 'high-amateur' mode" and wrote, "I would say they need to be less based on photographic reproduction. You can tell when someone is taking a found photograph and making a painting out of it [...] I think he'd be well advised to work from other, multiple photographic sources or the real person to get a little bit more liveliness going on."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[443]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legacy">Legacy</span></h2>
<p>President Bush's legacy continues to develop today. Supporters credit Bush's counterterrorism policies with preventing another major terrorist attack from occurring in the US after 9/11 and also praise individual policies such as the <a href="/wiki/Medicare_(United_States)" title="Medicare (United States)">Medicare</a> prescription drug benefit and the AIDS relief program known as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PEPFAR" title="PEPFAR">PEPFAR</a>.
