Critics often point to his handling of the <a href="/wiki/Iraq_War" title="Iraq War">Iraq War</a>, specifically the failure to find <a href="/wiki/Iraq_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Iraq and weapons of mass destruction">weapons of mass destruction</a>, that were the main rationale behind the initial invasion—as well as his handling of <a href="/wiki/Taxation_in_the_United_States" title="Taxation in the United States">tax policy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Katrina" title="Hurricane Katrina">Hurricane Katrina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">climate change</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2008_financial_crisis" title="2008 financial crisis">2008 financial crisis</a>—as proof that George W. Bush was unfit to be president.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444">[444]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445">[445]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-446"><a href="#cite_note-446">[446]</a></sup></p>
<p>Several historians and commentators hold the view that Bush was one of the most consequential presidents in American history. <a href="/wiki/Princeton_University" title="Princeton University">Princeton University</a> scholar Julian Zelizer described Bush's presidency as a "transformative" one, and said that "some people hate him, some people love him, but I do think he'll have a much more substantive perception as time goes on".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-447"><a href="#cite_note-447">[447]</a></sup> Bryon Williams of <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Huffington_Post" title="The Huffington Post">The Huffington Post</a></i> referred to Bush as "the most noteworthy president since <a href="/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Franklin D. Roosevelt">FDR</a>" and said that the <a href="/wiki/Patriot_Act" title="Patriot Act">Patriot Act</a> "increased authority of the executive branch at the expense of judicial opinions about when searches and seizures are reasonable" as evidence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-448"><a href="#cite_note-448">[448]</a></sup> Bush's administration presided over the largest tax cuts since the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reagan_administration" title="Reagan administration">Reagan administration</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-449"><a href="#cite_note-449">[449]</a></sup> and his homeland security reforms proved to be the most significant expansion of the federal government since the <a href="/wiki/Great_Society" title="Great Society">Great Society</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-450"><a href="#cite_note-450">[450]</a></sup> Much of these policies have endured in the administrations of his two immediate successors, <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> and <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-451"><a href="#cite_note-451">[451]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-452"><a href="#cite_note-452">[452]</a></sup> A 2010 <a href="/wiki/Siena_Research_Institute" title="Siena Research Institute">Siena Research Institute</a> survey of the opinions of historians, political scientists, and presidential scholars ranked him 39th out of 43 presidents. The survey respondents gave President Bush low ratings on his handling of the U.S. economy, communication, ability to compromise, foreign policy accomplishments, and intelligence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Siena_2010_453-0"><a href="#cite_note-Siena_2010-453">[453]</a></sup></p>
<p>Among the public, his reputation has improved somewhat since his presidency ended in 2009. In February 2012, Gallup reported that "Americans still rate George W. Bush among the worst presidents, though their views have become more positive in the three years since he left office."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gallup0212_454-0"><a href="#cite_note-gallup0212-454">[454]</a></sup> Gallup had earlier noted that Bush's favorability ratings in public opinion surveys had begun to rise a year after he had left office, from 40 percent in January 2009 and 35 percent in March 2009, to 45 percent in July 2010, a period during which he had remained largely out of the news.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-455"><a href="#cite_note-455">[455]</a></sup> Other pollsters have noted similar trends of slight improvement in Bush's personal favorability since the end of his presidency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pollingreport.com_456-0"><a href="#cite_note-pollingreport.com-456">[456]</a></sup> In April 2013, Bush's approval rating stood at 47 percent approval and 50 percent disapproval in a poll jointly conducted for <i><a href="/wiki/The_Washington_Post" title="The Washington Post">The Washington Post</a></i> and <a href="/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">ABC</a>, his highest approval rating since December 2005. Bush had achieved notable gains among seniors, non-college whites, and moderate and conservative Democrats since leaving office, although majorities disapproved of his handling of the economy (53 percent) and the Iraq War (57 percent).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-George_W._Bush.27s_approval_rating_just_hit_a_7-year_high._Here.27s_how._457-0"><a href="#cite_note-George_W._Bush.27s_approval_rating_just_hit_a_7-year_high._Here.27s_how.-457">[457]</a></sup> His 47 percent approval rating was equal to that of President Obama's in the same polling period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TheHill20130423_458-0"><a href="#cite_note-TheHill20130423-458">[458]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/CNN" title="CNN">CNN</a> poll conducted that same month found that 55 percent of Americans said Bush's presidency had been a failure, with opinions divided along party lines, and 43 percent of independents calling it a success.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-459"><a href="#cite_note-459">[459]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>

<li id="cite_note-Republican_right_abandoning_Bush-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Republican_right_abandoning_Bush_6-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Republican_right_abandoning_Bush_6-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news"><a class="external text" href="http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/12643666/" rel="nofollow">"Republican right abandoning Bush"</a>. <a href="/wiki/MSNBC" title="MSNBC">MSNBC</a>. <a href="/wiki/Associated_Press" title="Associated Press">Associated Press</a>. May 5, 2006. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080609042906/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/12643666/" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on June 9, 2008<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">June 23,</span> 2009</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AGeorge+W.+Bush&amp;rft.atitle=Republican+right+abandoning+Bush&amp;rft.date=2006-05-05&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.msnbc.msn.com%2Fid%2F12643666%2F&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-Kelley_Beaucar_Vlahos-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Kelley_Beaucar_Vlahos_7-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Kelley_Beaucar_Vlahos_7-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news">Kelley Beaucar Vlahos (February 13, 2006). <a class="external text" href="http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,184608,00.html" rel="nofollow">"Illegal Immigration, Unchecked Spending Siphon Conservatives From GOP Base"</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fox_News_Channel" title="Fox News Channel">Fox News Channel</a>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20090304202422/http://www.foxnews.com/story/0%2C2933%2C184608%2C00.html" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on March 4, 2009<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-243"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-243">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080225062850/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4673026.stm" rel="nofollow">"More Dutch troops for Afghanistan"</a>. BBC News. February 3, 2006. Archived from <a class="external text" href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4673026.stm" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on February 25, 2008<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">September 1,</span> 2008</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AGeorge+W.+Bush&amp;rft.atitle=More+Dutch+troops+for+Afghanistan&amp;rft.date=2006-02-03&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fnews.bbc.co.uk%2F2%2Fhi%2Feurope%2F4673026.stm&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-244"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-244">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Kristof, Nicholas D., <a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2002/02/01/opinion/a-merciful-war.html" rel="nofollow">"A Merciful War,"</a> <i>The New York Times</i>, February 1, 2002. "Now aid is pouring in and lives are being saved on an enormous scale. Unicef, for example, has vaccinated 734,000 children against measles over the last two months, in a country where virtually no one had been vaccinated against the disease in the previous 10 years. Because measles often led to death in Afghanistan, the vaccination campaign will save at least 35,000 children's lives each year... Heidi J. Larson of Unicef says that if all goes well, child and maternal mortality rates will drop in half in Afghanistan over the next five years. That would mean 112,000 fewer children and 7,500 fewer pregnant women dying each year."</span></li>

Retrieved <span class="nowrap">September 1,</span> 2008</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AGeorge+W.+Bush&amp;rft.btitle=Press+Briefing+by+Attorney+General+Alberto+Gonzales+and+General+Michael+Hayden&amp;rft.date=2005-12-19&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.pub=The+White+House&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fgeorgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov%2Fnews%2Freleases%2F2005%2F12%2F20051219-1.html&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-IG-275"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-IG_275-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation report">Inspectors General of the DoD, DOJ, CIA, NSA, and ODN (July 10, 2009). <a class="external text" href="http://www.webcitation.org/6i2nIRW6v?url=https://www.dni.gov/files/documents/Newsroom/Reports%20and%20Pubs/report_071309.pdf" rel="nofollow">Unclassified Report on the President's Surveillance Program</a> <span style="font-size:85%;">(PDF)</span> (Report). Archived from <a class="external text" href="https://www.dni.gov/files/documents/Newsroom/Reports%20and%20Pubs/report_071309.pdf" rel="nofollow">the original</a> <span style="font-size:85%;">(PDF, <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20131208042651/http://www.scribd.com/doc/17267628/Unclassified-Report-on-the-Presidents-Surveillance-Program" rel="nofollow">Scribd OCR</a> via archive.org)</span> on June 5, 2016<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">July 11,</span> 2009</span>. <q>The specific intelligence activities that were permitted by the Presidential Authorizations remain highly classified, except that beginning in December 2005 the President and other Administration officials acknowledged that these activities included the interception without a court order of certain international communications where there is "a reasonable basis to conclude that one party to the communication is a member of al-Qa'ida, affiliated with al-Qa'ida, or a member of an organization affiliated with al-Qa'ida."</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AGeorge+W.+Bush&amp;rft.au=Inspectors+General+of+the+DoD%2C+DOJ%2C+CIA%2C+NSA%2C+and+ODN&amp;rft.btitle=Unclassified+Report+on+the+President%27s+Surveillance+Program&amp;rft.date=2009-07-10&amp;rft.genre=report&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.dni.gov%2Ffiles%2Fdocuments%2FNewsroom%2FReports%2520and%2520Pubs%2Freport_071309.pdf&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span><span class="citation-comment" style="display:none; color:#33aa33; margin-left:0.3em">CS1 maint: Multiple names: authors list (<a href="/wiki/Category:CS1_maint:_Multiple_names:_authors_list" title="Category:CS1 maint: Multiple names: authors list">link</a>)</span></span></li>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Further_reading">Further reading</span></h2>
<div class="refbegin columns references-column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em;">
<p><b>Academic</b></p>
<ul>
<li>Abramson, Paul R., John H. Aldrich, and David W. Rohde. <i>Change and Continuity in the 2004 and 2006 Elections</i> (2007), 324pp <a class="external text" href="https://www.amazon.com/dp/0872894150" rel="nofollow">excerpt and text search</a></li>
<li>Allard, Scott W. "The Changing Face of Welfare During the Bush Administration." <i>Publius</i> 2007 37(3): 304–332. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_Standard_Serial_Number_(identifier)" title="International Standard Serial Number (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="https://www.worldcat.org/search?fq=x0:jrnl&amp;q=n2:0048-5950" rel="nofollow">0048-5950</a></li>
<li>Barone, Michael. <i>The Almanac of American Politics</i> (2004, 2006, 2008, 2010), highly detailed coverage of electoral politics and Congress.</li>
<li>Berggren, D. Jason, and Nicol C. Rae. "Jimmy Carter and George W. Bush: Faith, Foreign Policy, and an Evangelical Presidential Style." <i>Presidential Studies Quarterly.</i> 36#4 2006. pp 606+. <a class="external text" href="https://www.questia.com/PM.qst?a=o&amp;d=5018322436" rel="nofollow">online edition</a></li>
<li>Campbell, Colin, Bert A. Rockman, and Andrew Rudalevige, eds.. <i>The George W. Bush Legacy</i> Congressional Quarterly Press, 2007, 352pp; 14 essays by scholars <a class="external text" href="https://www.amazon.com/dp/0872893464" rel="nofollow">excerpts and online search from Amazon.com</a></li>
<li>Congressional Quarterly. <i>CQ Almanac Plus</i> highly detailed annual compilation of events in Congress, White House, Supreme Court, summarizing the weekly "Congressional Quarterly Weekly Report". (annual, 2002–2009)</li>
<li>Conlan, Tim and John Dinan. "Federalism, the Bush Administration, and the Transformation of American Conservatism." <i>Publius</i> 2007 37(3): 279–303. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_Standard_Serial_Number_(identifier)" title="International Standard Serial Number (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="https://www.worldcat.org/search?fq=x0:jrnl&amp;q=n2:0048-5950" rel="nofollow">0048-5950</a></li>
<li>Corrado, Anthony, E. J. Dionne Jr., Kathleen A. Frankovic. <i>The Election of 2000: Reports and Interpretations</i> (2001) <a class="external text" href="https://www.questia.com/PM.qst?a=o&amp;d=99208680" rel="nofollow">online edition</a></li>
<li>Daynes, Byron W. and Glen Sussman. "Comparing the Environmental Policies of Presidents George H. W. Bush and George W. Bush." <i>White House Studies</i> 2007 7(2): 163–179. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_Standard_Serial_Number_(identifier)" title="International Standard Serial Number (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="https://www.worldcat.org/search?fq=x0:jrnl&amp;q=n2:1535-4768" rel="nofollow">1535-4768</a></li>
<li>Desch, Michael C. "Bush and the Generals." <i>Foreign Affairs</i> 2007 86(3): 97–108. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_Standard_Serial_Number_(identifier)" title="International Standard Serial Number (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="https://www.worldcat.org/search?fq=x0:jrnl&amp;q=n2:0015-7120" rel="nofollow">0015-7120</a> Fulltext: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ebsco" title="Ebsco">Ebsco</a></li>
<li>Eckersley, Robyn. "Ambushed: the Kyoto Protocol, the Bush Administration's Climate Policy and the Erosion of Legitimacy." <i>International Politics</i> 2007 44(2–3): 306–324. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_Standard_Serial_Number_(identifier)" title="International Standard Serial Number (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="https://www.worldcat.org/search?fq=x0:jrnl&amp;q=n2:1384-5748" rel="nofollow">1384-5748</a></li>
<li>Edwards III, George C. and Philip John Davies, eds. <i>New Challenges for the American Presidency</i> New York: Pearson Longman, 2004. 245 pp. articles from <i>Presidential Studies Quarterly</i></li>
<li>Edwards III, George C. and Desmond King, eds. <i>The Polarized Presidency of George W. Bush</i> (2007), 478pp; essays by scholars; <a class="external text" href="https://www.amazon.com/gp/reader/0199217971" rel="nofollow">excerpt and online search from Amazon.com</a></li>
<li>Fortier, John C. and Norman J. Ornstein, eds. <i>Second-term Blues: How George W. Bush Has Governed</i> (2007), 146pp <a class="external text" href="https://www.amazon.com/gp/reader/0815728840" rel="nofollow">excerpt and online search from Amazon.com</a></li>
<li>Graham John D. <i>Bush on the Home Front: Domestic Policy Triumphs and Setbacks</i> (Indiana University Press, 2010) 425 pages; covers taxation, education, health care, energy, the environment, and regulatory reform.</li>
<li>Greenstein, Fred I. ed. <i>The George W. Bush Presidency: An Early Assessment</i> Johns Hopkins University Press, 2003</li>
<li>Greenstein, Fred I. "The Contemporary Presidency: The Changing Leadership of George W. Bush A Pre- and Post-9/11 Comparison" in <i>Presidential Studies Quarterly</i> v 32#2 2002 pp 387+. <a class="external text" href="https://www.questia.com/PM.qst?a=o&amp;d=5000773171" rel="nofollow">online edition</a></li>
<li>Gregg II, Gary L. and Mark J. Rozell, eds. <i>Considering the Bush Presidency</i> Oxford University Press, 2004. 210 pp. British perspectives</li>
<li>Hendrickson, Ryan C., and Kristina Spohr Readman, "From the Baltic to the Black Sea: Bush's NATO Enlargement." <i>White House Studies.</i> (2004) 4#3 pp: 319+. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20110426162034/http://www.questia.com/PM.qst?a=o&amp;d=5008838303" rel="nofollow">online edition</a></li>
<li>Hilliard, Bryan, Tom Lansford, and Robert P Watson, eds. <i>George W. Bush: Evaluating the President at Midterm</i> SUNY Press 2004</li>
<li>Jacobson, Gary C. "The Bush Presidency and the American Electorate" <i>Presidential Studies Quarterly</i> v 33 No.4 2003 pp 701+. <a class="external text" href="https://www.questia.com/PM.qst?a=o&amp;d=5002052614" rel="nofollow">online edition</a></li>
<li>Jacobson, Gary C. "Referendum: the 2006 Midterm Congressional Elections." <i>Political Science Quarterly</i> 2007 122(1): 1–24. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_Standard_Serial_Number_(identifier)" title="International Standard Serial Number (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="https://www.worldcat.org/search?fq=x0:jrnl&amp;q=n2:0032-3195" rel="nofollow">0032-3195</a> Fulltext: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ebsco" title="Ebsco">Ebsco</a></li>
<li>Milkis, Sidney M. and Jesse H.Rhodes. "George W. Bush, the Party System, and American Federalism." <i>Publius</i> 2007 37(3): 478–503. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_Standard_Serial_Number_(identifier)" title="International Standard Serial Number (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="https://www.worldcat.org/search?fq=x0:jrnl&amp;q=n2:0048-5950" rel="nofollow">0048-5950</a></li>

<li>Rabe, Barry. "Environmental Policy and the Bush Era: the Collision Between the Administrative Presidency and State Experimentation." <i>Publius</i> 2007 37(3): 413–431. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_Standard_Serial_Number_(identifier)" title="International Standard Serial Number (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="https://www.worldcat.org/search?fq=x0:jrnl&amp;q=n2:0048-5950" rel="nofollow">0048-5950</a></li>

Simon &amp; Schuster.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AGeorge+W.+Bush&amp;rft.aufirst=Jean+Edward&amp;rft.aulast=Smith&amp;rft.btitle=Bush&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.pub=Simon+%26+Schuster&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></li>

<p><b>Reflections on the Bush presidency</b></p>
<ul>

<li><a href="/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_the_United_States" title="List of Presidents of the United States">43rd</a> <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">President of the United States</a> (2001–2009)</li>

</ul>

<li><a href="/wiki/John_Quincy_Adams" title="John Quincy Adams">John Q. Adams</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_John_Quincy_Adams" title="Presidency of John Quincy Adams">1825–1829</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Andrew_Jackson" title="Andrew Jackson">Andrew Jackson</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Andrew_Jackson" title="Presidency of Andrew Jackson">1829–1837</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Martin_Van_Buren" title="Martin Van Buren">Martin Van Buren</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Martin_Van_Buren" title="Presidency of Martin Van Buren">1837–1841</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/William_Henry_Harrison" title="William Henry Harrison">William H. Harrison</a> <small><i>(<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Presidency_of_William_Henry_Harrison" title="Presidency of William Henry Harrison">1841</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/John_Tyler" title="John Tyler">John Tyler</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_John_Tyler" title="Presidency of John Tyler">1841–1845</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/James_K._Polk" title="James K. Polk">James K. Polk</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_James_K._Polk" title="Presidency of James K. Polk">1845–1849</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Zachary_Taylor" title="Zachary Taylor">Zachary Taylor</a> <small><i>(<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Zachary_Taylor" title="Presidency of Zachary Taylor">1849–1850</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Millard_Fillmore" title="Millard Fillmore">Millard Fillmore</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Millard_Fillmore" title="Presidency of Millard Fillmore">1850–1853</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Franklin_Pierce" title="Franklin Pierce">Franklin Pierce</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Franklin_Pierce" title="Presidency of Franklin Pierce">1853–1857</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/James_Buchanan" title="James Buchanan">James Buchanan</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_James_Buchanan" title="Presidency of James Buchanan">1857–1861</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln" title="Abraham Lincoln">Abraham Lincoln</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Abraham_Lincoln" title="Presidency of Abraham Lincoln">1861–1865</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Andrew_Johnson" title="Andrew Johnson">Andrew Johnson</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Andrew_Johnson" title="Presidency of Andrew Johnson">1865–1869</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ulysses_S._Grant" title="Ulysses S. Grant">Ulysses S. Grant</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Ulysses_S._Grant" title="Presidency of Ulysses S. Grant">1869–1877</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Rutherford_B._Hayes" title="Rutherford B. Hayes">Rutherford B. Hayes</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Rutherford_B._Hayes" title="Presidency of Rutherford B. Hayes">1877–1881</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/James_A._Garfield" title="James A. Garfield">James A. Garfield</a> <small><i>(<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Presidency_of_James_A._Garfield" title="Presidency of James A. Garfield">1881</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Chester_A._Arthur" title="Chester A. Arthur">Chester A. Arthur</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Chester_A._Arthur" title="Presidency of Chester A. Arthur">1881–1885</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Grover_Cleveland" title="Grover Cleveland">Grover Cleveland</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidencies_of_Grover_Cleveland" title="Presidencies of Grover Cleveland">1885–1889</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Harrison" title="Benjamin Harrison">Benjamin Harrison</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Benjamin_Harrison" title="Presidency of Benjamin Harrison">1889–1893</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Grover_Cleveland" title="Grover Cleveland">Grover Cleveland</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidencies_of_Grover_Cleveland" title="Presidencies of Grover Cleveland">1893–1897</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/William_McKinley" title="William McKinley">William McKinley</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_William_McKinley" title="Presidency of William McKinley">1897–1901</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt" title="Theodore Roosevelt">Theodore Roosevelt</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Theodore_Roosevelt" title="Presidency of Theodore Roosevelt">1901–1909</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/William_Howard_Taft" title="William Howard Taft">William H. Taft</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_William_Howard_Taft" title="Presidency of William Howard Taft">1909–1913</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson" title="Woodrow Wilson">Woodrow Wilson</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Woodrow_Wilson" title="Presidency of Woodrow Wilson">1913–1921</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Warren_G._Harding" title="Warren G. Harding">Warren G. Harding</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Warren_G._Harding" title="Presidency of Warren G. Harding">1921–1923</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge" title="Calvin Coolidge">Calvin Coolidge</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Calvin_Coolidge" title="Presidency of Calvin Coolidge">1923–1929</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Herbert_Hoover" title="Herbert Hoover">Herbert Hoover</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Herbert_Hoover" title="Presidency of Herbert Hoover">1929–1933</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Franklin D. Roosevelt">Franklin D. Roosevelt</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Presidency of Franklin D. Roosevelt">1933–1945</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Harry_S._Truman" title="Harry S. Truman">Harry S. Truman</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Harry_S._Truman" title="Presidency of Harry S. Truman">1945–1953</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Dwight_D._Eisenhower" title="Dwight D. Eisenhower">Dwight D. Eisenhower</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Dwight_D._Eisenhower" title="Presidency of Dwight D. Eisenhower">1953–1961</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy" title="John F. Kennedy">John F. Kennedy</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_John_F._Kennedy" title="Presidency of John F. Kennedy">1961–1963</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Lyndon_B._Johnson" title="Lyndon B. Johnson">Lyndon B. Johnson</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Lyndon_B._Johnson" title="Presidency of Lyndon B. Johnson">1963–1969</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Richard_Nixon" title="Richard Nixon">Richard Nixon</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Richard_Nixon" title="Presidency of Richard Nixon">1969–1974</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Gerald_Ford" title="Gerald Ford">Gerald Ford</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Gerald_Ford" title="Presidency of Gerald Ford">1974–1977</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Carter" title="Jimmy Carter">Jimmy Carter</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Jimmy_Carter" title="Presidency of Jimmy Carter">1977–1981</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Ronald_Reagan" title="Presidency of Ronald Reagan">1981–1989</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/George_H._W._Bush" title="George H. W. Bush">George H. W. Bush</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_George_H._W._Bush" title="Presidency of George H. W. Bush">1989–1993</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Bill_Clinton" title="Bill Clinton">Bill Clinton</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Bill_Clinton" title="Presidency of Bill Clinton">1993–2001</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a class="mw-selflink selflink">George W. Bush</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_George_W._Bush" title="Presidency of George W. Bush">2001–2009</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Barack_Obama" title="Presidency of Barack Obama">2009–2017</a>)</i></small></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> <small><i>(<a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Donald_Trump" title="Presidency of Donald Trump">2017–present</a>)</i></small></li>

<div id="Time_Persons_of_the_Year" style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em"><a href="/wiki/Time_Person_of_the_Year" title="Time Person of the Year"><i>Time</i> Persons of the Year</a></div>

<tr>
<th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">1927–1950</th>
<td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">
<div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul>
<li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Charles_Lindbergh" title="Charles Lindbergh">Charles Lindbergh</a> (1927)</span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Walter_Chrysler" title="Walter Chrysler">Walter Chrysler</a> (1928)</span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Owen_D._Young" title="Owen D. Young">Owen D. Young</a> (1929)</span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi" title="Mahatma Gandhi">Mohandas Gandhi</a> (1930)</span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Pierre_Laval" title="Pierre Laval">Pierre Laval</a> (1931)</span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Franklin D. Roosevelt">Franklin D. Roosevelt</a> (1932)</span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Hugh_S._Johnson" title="Hugh S. Johnson">Hugh S. Johnson</a> (1933)</span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Franklin D. Roosevelt">Franklin D. Roosevelt</a> (1934)</span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Haile_Selassie" title="Haile Selassie">Haile Selassie</a> (1935)</span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Wallis_Simpson" title="Wallis Simpson">Wallis Simpson</a> (1936)</span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Chiang_Kai-shek" title="Chiang Kai-shek">Chiang Kai-shek</a> / <a href="/wiki/Soong_Mei-ling" title="Soong Mei-ling">Soong Mei-ling</a> (1937)</span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Adolf_Hitler" title="Adolf Hitler">Adolf Hitler</a> (1938)</span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin" title="Joseph Stalin">Joseph Stalin</a> (1939)</span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Winston Churchill</a> (1940)</span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Franklin D. Roosevelt">Franklin D. Roosevelt</a> (1941)</span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin" title="Joseph Stalin">Joseph Stalin</a> (1942)</span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/George_Marshall" title="George Marshall">George Marshall</a> (1943)</span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Dwight_D._Eisenhower" title="Dwight D. Eisenhower">Dwight D. Eisenhower</a> (1944)</span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Harry_S._Truman" title="Harry S. Truman">Harry S. Truman</a> (1945)</span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/James_F._Byrnes" title="James F. Byrnes">James F. Byrnes</a> (1946)</span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/George_Marshall" title="George Marshall">George Marshall</a> (1947)</span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Harry_S._Truman" title="Harry S. Truman">Harry S. Truman</a> (1948)</span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Winston Churchill</a> (1949)</span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">The American Fighting-Man</a> (1950)</span></li>
</ul>
</div>
</td>
</tr>

<th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%"><a href="/wiki/List_of_United_States_Republican_Party_presidential_tickets" title="List of United States Republican Party presidential tickets">Presidential tickets</a></th>
<td class="navbox-list navbox-even" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">
<div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/John_C._Fr%C3%A9mont" title="John C. Frémont">Frémont</a>/<a href="/wiki/William_L._Dayton" title="William L. Dayton">Dayton</a></li>

<div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Omnibus_Crime_Control_and_Safe_Streets_Act_of_1968" title="Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968">Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968</a></i></li>

<li><i><a href="/wiki/Foreign_Intelligence_Surveillance_Act" title="Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act">Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act</a></i></li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Family_Educational_Rights_and_Privacy_Act" title="Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act">Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act</a></i></li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Money_Laundering_Control_Act" title="Money Laundering Control Act">Money Laundering Control Act</a></i></li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Bank_Secrecy_Act" title="Bank Secrecy Act">Bank Secrecy Act</a></i></li>

<li><i><a href="/wiki/Immigration_and_Nationality_Act_of_1952" title="Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952">Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952</a></i></li>
